[[Ben Washam]] | animator = [[Charles McKimson]]
Herman Cohen
Rod Scribner
[[Phil DeLara]] | layout_artist = Robert Givens | background_artist = Richard H. Thomas | voice_actor = [[Mel Blanc]] | narrator = [[Robert C. Bruce]] (uncredited) | musician = [[Carl Stalling]] | producer = [[Eddie Selzer|Edward Selzer]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros. Pictures]]
[[The Vitaphone Corporation]] | release_date = September 4, 1954 (USA) | color_process = [[Technicolor]] | runtime = 7:00 | movie_language = English |}} '''''Gone Batty''''' is a ''[[Looney Tunes]]'' animated cartoon short released by Warner Brothers on September 4, 1954. The film was re-released in October 1963 as a ''[[Merrie Melodies]]'' [[Blue ribbon|Blue Ribbon]] cartoon. ==Plot== {{expand section|date=August 2012}} Bobo the Elephant, making his first appearance since ''[[Hobo Bobo]]'', also directed by [[Robert McKimson|McKimson]], is baseball team mascot for the lean and meek Sweetwater Shnooks, all of whom are rendered unconscious by their opponents, the husky and brutal Greenville Goons. Just as a victory by the Goons seems nearly inevitable, Bobo singlehandedly rallies his team back for a win in the bottom of the ninth inning. ==Overview== Robert McKimson directed the animated cartoon from a story (lifted in part from the [[Friz Freleng]]/[[Michael Maltese]] 1946 opus ''[[Baseball Bugs]]'') by Sid Marcus and animator [[Ben Washam]]. Animation was done from Robert Givens' layout by [[Charles McKimson]], Herman Cohen, Rod Scribner and Phil DeLara with backgrounds by Richard H. Thomas and music by [[Carl Stalling]]. Voices were provided by [[Mel Blanc]] and an uncredited [[Robert C. Bruce]] as a play-by-play announcer. == External links == * {{IMDb title|0047038}} [[Category:1954 films]] [[Category:1954 animated films]] [[Category:1950s American animated films]] [[Category:1950s animated short films]] [[Category:1950s sports films]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:Baseball animation]] [[Category:Animated films about elephants]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert McKimson]] [[Category:Looney Tunes shorts]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films scored by Carl Stalling]] {{LooneyTunes-stub}}

[[File:91hankycrop.jpg|thumb|A 1991 Homer Hanky]]
The '''Official [[Star Tribune]] [[Minnesota Twins]] Homer Hanky''' (or "Homer Hanky" for short) is a [[handkerchief]] printed with a (usually red) [[baseball]]-shaped logo during Minnesota Twins championship seasons (and in 1988 after winning the World Series in 1987). It was first introduced during the 1987 Pennant race, when the Twins won the [[American League]] Western division (AL West), by the'' ''Minneapolis ''Star Tribune'' as a promotional item for the newspaper during the pennant race.<ref>{{cite news | first=Ben | last=Tracy | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Good Question: What Is The Homer Hanky's History? | date=Oct 4, 2006 | publisher=CBS Broadcasting Inc. | url =http://wcco.com/goodquestion/Good.Question.Homer.2.362040.html | work =WCCO | pages = | accessdate = 2009-01-13 | language = }}</ref> {{TOC right}}
==Years==
===1987=== {{main|1987 in baseball|1987 Minnesota Twins season}} * ''1987'': Red, baseball-shaped logo. ** Printed at the end of the season ** Created by Star Tribune promotions manager Terrie Robbins<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Good Question: What is the Homer Hanky's History? | date=Oct 4, 2006 | publisher=CBS Broadcasting | url =http://wcco.com/goodquestion/Good.Question.Homer.2.362040.html | work =WCCO.com | pages = | accessdate = 2009-01-13 | language = }}</ref> ** Twins won [[1987 World Series|World Series]] (4–1 [[1987 American League Championship Series|ALCS]]def Detroit Tigers, 4–3 WS, def St. Louis Cardinals)<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Minnesota Twins Owner Carl Pohlad Dies At 93 | date=Jan 5, 2009 | publisher=Associated Press | url =http://wcco.com/sports/Carl.Pohlad.dies.2.900562.html | work =WCCO.com | pages = | accessdate = 2009-01-13 | language = }}</ref>
===1988=== {{main|1988 in baseball|1988 Minnesota Twins season}} * ''1988'': Red, [[baseball diamond]]-shaped logo. ** Printed at the beginning of the season ** Twins finished 2nd in AL West behind the [[Oakland A's]]
===1989–1990=== Gap between 1989 and 1990
===1991–1992=== {{main|1991 in baseball|1991 Minnesota Twins season}} * ''1991'': Red, baseball-shaped logo. ** Printed at the end of the season ** Twins won [[1991 World Series|World Series]] (4-1 [[1991 American League Championship Series|ALCS]] def Toronto Blue Jays, 4-3 WS, def Atlanta Braves) * ''1992'': Red, baseball-shaped logo. ** Printed at the beginning of the season ** Twins finished 2nd in AL West behind the Oakland A's
===1993–2001=== Gap between 1993 and 2001 1997 Homer Hanky was printed marking the 10th anniversary of the 1987 season.
1987 10th Anniversary
===2002=== {{main|2002 in baseball|2002 Minnesota Twins season}} * ''2002'': Red, baseball-shaped logo. ** Printed at the end of the season ** Twins won AL Central and [[2002 American League Division Series|AL Division Series]] (def. Oakland A's 3–2) but lost [[2002 American League Championship Series|AL Championship Series]] to [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|Anaheim Angels]] (1–4). In 2002 there seems to be two sizes of the Homer Hanky "Proud and Loud". A larger and "normal" size of 15{{fraction|1|2}} inch square and a smaller size of 13{{fraction|1|2}} inches square with "hanky stitching" on the edge.
===2003=== {{main|2003 in baseball|2003 Minnesota Twins season}} * ''2003'': Blue, baseball-shaped logo. ** Printed at the end of the season ** Twins won AL Central but lost [[2003 American League Division Series|AL Division Series]] to [[New York Yankees]] (1–3).
===2004=== {{main|2004 in baseball|2004 Minnesota Twins season}} [[File:2004 Minnesota Twins Homer Hanky.jpg|thumb|2004 Hanky]] * ''2004'': Red, outline of a baseball field ** Printed at the end of the season ** Twins won AL Central but lost [[2004 American League Division Series|AL Division Series]] to New York Yankees (1–3).
===2004–2005=== Gap between 2004 and 2005
===2006=== {{main|2006 in baseball|2006 Minnesota Twins season}} * ''2006'': Red, State of MN with Minneapolis and St. Paul baseball player shaking hands (similar to the Twins logo from 1961 to 1986) * Twins won AL Central on the last day of the regular season, October 1, 2006 * Twins lost in the [[2006 American League Division Series|ALDS]] to the [[Oakland Athletics]] (0–3) ** Printed at the end of the season, available September 28, 2006
===2007–2008=== Gap between 2007 and 2008
===2009=== * Homer Hankies were given to all fans during what was to be the last regular season game at the Metrodome on October 4, 2009. * On October 6, 2009, the ''Star Tribune'' and the Minnesota Twins announced that there would be a 2009 Homer Hanky available.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/press_releases/press_release.jsp?ymd=20091007&content_id=7385162&vkey=pr_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|title=AL Central Division Champion Minnesota Twins Announce the Homer Hanky is Back|work=Minnesota Twins}}</ref> * Twins won AL Central after beating the Detroit Tigers in one game playoff to determine the division champion on October 6.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://minnesota.twins.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20091007&content_id=7376368&vkey=news_min&fext=.jsp&c_id=min|title=Tiebreaker filled with intense drama|work=Minnesota Twins}}</ref>
===2010=== * Homer Hankies were given to all fans before the 2010 Home Opener at [[Target Field]]. These Hankies featured the official Target Field inaugural season logo and the words "The Official Opening Day Homer Hanky" across the top, and "April 12th, 2010 Twins vs. Red Sox" across the bottom. * On September 22, the Twins introduced a 2010 Championship Hanky.
===2014=== * Homer Hankies were released for All-Star Week on July 11th, 2014. These hankies featured a red Minnesota outline and "All Star Week 2014" in blue.
==See also== * [[Handy horn]] * [[Rally towel]] * [[Terrible Towel]] * [[Vuvuzela]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

[[File:Indirect calorimetry laboratory with canopy hood.jpg|thumb|Indirect calorimetry metabolic cart measuring oxygen uptake (O<sub>2</sub>) and carbon dioxide production (CO<sub>2</sub>) of a spontaneously breathing subject (dilution method with canopy hood).]] '''Indirect calorimetry''' calculates [[heat]] that [[Organism|living organisms]] produce by measuring either their production of [[carbon dioxide]] and [[Metabolic waste|nitrogen waste]] (frequently [[ammonia]] in aquatic organisms, or [[urea]] in terrestrial ones), or from their consumption of [[oxygen]]. Indirect calorimetry is the method by which the type and rate of substrate utilization, and [[energy metabolism]] are estimated in vivo starting from [[gas exchange]] measurements (carbon dioxide production and oxygen consumption during rest and steady-state exercise). This technique provides unique information, is noninvasive, and can be advantageously combined with other experimental methods to investigate numerous aspects of nutrient assimilation, [[thermogenesis]], the [[energetics]] of physical exercise, and the [[pathogenesis]] of [[Metabolic disorders|metabolic diseases]].<ref name="Ferrannini">Ferrannini E.[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3278194 "The theoretical bases of indirect calorimetry: a review."] Metabolism. 1988 Mar;37(3):287-301.</ref>
==Scientific background== Indirect calorimetry measures O<sub>2</sub> consumption and CO<sub>2</sub> production. On the assumption that all the oxygen is used to [[oxidize]] degradable fuels and all the CO<sub>2</sub>, thereby evolved is recovered, it is possible to calculate the total amount of energy produced. It should be clear that “energy production” means conversion of the chemical free-energy of nutrients into the chemical energy of [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] plus loss of some energy during the oxidation process.<ref name="Ferrannini"/> Respiratory indirect [[calorimetry]], or indirect calorimetry (IC) as it is known by most authors, is a noninvasive and highly accurate method of [[Basal metabolic rate|metabolic rate]] which has an error rate lower than 1%.<ref name="Marson">Marson F, et al. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21892558 "Correlation between oxygen consumption calculated using Fick's method and measured with indirect calorimetry in critically ill patients."] Arq Bras Cardiol. 2004 Jan;82(1):77-81, 72-6. Epub 2004 Feb 12.</ref> It has high reproducibility and has been considered a gold standard method.<ref name="Haugen">Haugen HA, et al. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17644692 "Indirect calorimetry: a practical guide for clinicians."] Nutr Clin Pract. 2007 Aug;22(4):377-88.</ref> This method allows estimating [[Basal metabolic rate|BEE]] and [[Resting metabolic rate|REE]], and also allows for identification of energy substrates that are being predominantly metabolized by the body at a specific moment. It is based on the indirect measure of the heat produced by oxidation of [[macronutrients]], which is estimated by monitoring oxygen consumption (O<sub>2</sub>) and carbon dioxide production (CO<sub>2</sub>) for a certain period of time.<ref name="Pinheiro">Pinheiro Volp AC, et al. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21892558 "Energy expenditure: components and evaluation methods."] Nutr Hosp. 2011 May-Jun;26(3):430-40. doi: 10.1590/S0212-16112011000300002.</ref> The [[calorimeter]] has a gas collector that adapts to the subject and a system that measures the volume and concentrations of O<sub>2</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> minute by minute. Through a unidirectional valve, the calorimeter collects and quantifies the volume and concentration of O<sub>2</sub> inspired and CO<sub>2</sub> expired by the subject. After a volume is met, [[Resting metabolic rate|Resting Energy Expenditure]] is calculated by the [[Weir formula]] and results are displayed in software attached to the system.<ref name="Pinheiro"/> Another formula used is:<ref>{{cite journal|last1=A.R. Bain et al|title=Body heat storage during physical activity is lower with hot fluid ingestion under conditions that permit full evaporation Authors|journal=[[Acta Physiologica]]|date=Jun 2012|doi=10.1111/j.1748-1716.2012.02452.x}} citing {{cite book|last1=Nishi|first1=Y.|editor1-last=K. Cena & J. Clark|title=Bioengineering, Thermal Physiology and Comfort|date=1981|publisher=Elsevier|pages=29–39|chapter=Measurement of thermal balance in man}}</ref> :<math>M=VO_2\left(\frac{RQ-0.7}{0.3}e_c+\frac{1-RQ}{0.3}e_f\right)</math> where RQ is the [[respiratory quotient]] (ratio of volume CO<sub>2</sub> produced to volume of O<sub>2</sub> consumed), <math>e_c</math> is {{convert|21.13|kJ|kcal}}, the heat released per litre of oxygen by the oxidation of carbohydrate, and <math>e_f</math> is {{convert|19.62|kJ|kcal}}, the value for fat. This gives the same result as the Weir formula at RQ = 1 (burning only carbohydrates), and almost the same value at RQ = 0.7 (burning only fat). ⊅∑′
==History== [[Antoine Lavoisier]] noted in 1780 that heat production can be predicted from oxygen consumption, using multiple regression. The [[Dynamic energy budget|Dynamic Energy Budget]] theory explains why this procedure is correct. Indirect calorimetry, as we know it, was developed at the turn of the century’s as an application of [[thermodynamics]] to animal life.<ref name="Atwater">Atwater WO, et al. [http://www.sportsci.org/news/history/atwater/atwater.html "Description of neo respiration calorimeter and experiments on the conservation of energy in the human body."] US Department Agriculture, Off Exp Sta Bull 63, 1899</ref> Although the development of indirect calorimetry dates back over 200 years, its greatest use has been in the last two decades with the development of total [[parenteral nutrition]], interdisciplinary nutrition support teams, and the production of portable, reliable, relatively inexpensive calorimeters.<ref name="McClave">McClave SA, et al. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1289691 "Use of indirect calorimetry in clinical nutrition."] Nutr Clin Pract. 1992 Oct;7(5):207-21.</ref>
==Collection methods== Four different gas collection and measurement techniques can be used to perform this test: *'''Douglas Bag''': expired respiratory gases are collected on an inflatable airtight bag.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Douglas, C. Gordon|authorlink=Claude Gordon Douglas|title=A method for determining the total respiratory exchange in man|journal=Proceedings of the Physiological Society|date=18 March 1911|url=http://digitalcommons.ohsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1195&context=hca-cac}} ('''Douglas Bag''')</ref> After completion of any test using Douglas Bags, gas collected must be analysed for volume and composition. *'''Canopy''' (dilution): The dilution technique is considered the gold standard technology for Resting Energy Expenditure measurement in clinical nutrition.<ref name="Haugen"/> The test lasts just few minutes and consists of making a patient lie down relaxed on a bed or on a comfortable couch, with the head under a transparent hood connected to a pump, which applies an adjustable ventilation through it. Exhaled gas dilutes with the fresh air ventilated under the hood and a sample of this mixture is conveyed to the analysers, through a capillary tube and analysed. Ambient and diluted fractions of O<sub>2</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> are measured for a known ventilation rate, and O<sub>2</sub> consumption and CO<sub>2</sub> production are determined and converted into Resting Energy Expenditure.<ref name="ADA">Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics [http://www.andeal.org/ "Measuring RMR with Indirect Calorimetry (IC)."] Nutr Clin Pract. 2007 Aug;22(4):377-88.</ref> *'''Face mask''' (breath by breath): Indirect calorimetry tests are also often performed with a face mask, which is used to convey exhaled and inhaled gas through a turbine [[Flow measurement|flowmeter]] able to measure the patient’s breath by breath minute ventilation, at the same time a sample of gas is conveyed to the analyser and VO<sub>2</sub> and VCO<sub>2</sub> are measured and converted in energy expenditure. *'''Interface with a Ventilator''' ([[Intensive care unit|Intensive Care]] settings): In case the patient is mechanically ventilated, an indirect calorimeter can still measure breath by breath inhaled/exhaled O<sub>2</sub> and CO<sub>2</sub> if interfaced with the ventilator through the [[Tracheal tube|endotracheal tube]].
==Applications== Indirect calorimetry provides at least two pieces of information: a measure of energy expenditure or 24-hour caloric requirements as reflected by the [[Resting metabolic rate|Resting Energy Expenditure]] (REE) and a measure of substrate utilization as reflected in the [[Respiratory quotient|Respiratory Quotient]] (RQ). Knowledge of the many factors that affect these values has led to a much broader range of applications. Studies of indirect calorimetry over the past 20 years have led to the characterization of the [[Hypermetabolism|hypermetabolic]] stress response to injury and the design of nutritional regimens whose substrates are most efficiently assimilated in different disease processes and [[organ failure]] states. Indirect calorimetry has influenced everyday practices of medical and surgical care, such as the warming of [[Burn center|burn unit]] and surgical suites and the weaning of patients from [[Medical ventilator|ventilators]].<ref name="McClave"/>
==References== <references/>
==See also== * [http://www.andeal.org/ "Measuring RMR with Indirect Calorimetry (IC)" Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics - Evidence Analysis Library] * [http://ajcn.nutrition.org/ American Journal of Clinical Nutrition]

{{redirect-distinguish|infront|Out Front (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox company | name = Infront Sports & Media | logo = Infront_Sports_and_Media_logo_NEW.svg | logo_size = 180px | caption = | type = Sports & Media | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{start date and age|2002|10}} | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Zug]] | location_country = [[Switzerland]] | location = | locations = 35 | area_served = | key_people = Philippe Blatter (President and CEO)<ref name = Variety2>https://variety.com/2015/biz/asia/shanghai-groups-join-wanda-in-infront-sports-deal-1201541457/?_sm_au_=iVVMPH2pvWNNDPM3</ref><ref name = Guardian2>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/feb/11/china-wanda-buys-infront-sports-media</ref><ref name = variety3>https://variety.com/2016/digital/asia/wanda-owned-infront-ceo-philippe-blatter-china-sports-buying-spree-1201854714/</ref> | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 900 | parent = [[Dalian Wanda Group]] (among others) | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.infrontsports.com/ infrontsports.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Infront Sports & Media''' is a [[sports marketing]] company based in [[Zug]], [[Switzerland]]. The company handles the media and marketing rights for international sports events and federations and also provides sports services - such as advertising, sponsorship and hospitality. It represents all seven Olympic winter sport federations,<ref>{{cite web |author=David Owen|url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/sports/winter/skating/1025400-infront-to-acquire-dutch-agency-specialising-in-speed-skating |title=Infront to acquire Dutch agency specialising in speed skating|publisher=www.insidethegames.biz|date= |accessdate=2015-02-07}}</ref> several summer sport organizations and manages media rights for the FIS World Cup Events. Infront was created in late 2002 through the integration of CWL, Prisma and KirchSportAG. It has 35 offices, which belong to different subsidiaries for geographic regions.
==History== Infront Sports & Media was founded in October 2002 in order to create the television and radio broadcasts for the 2002 FIFA World Cup.<ref name="dakfhj">http://www.prosoundnetwork.com/article/fifa-drives-audio-innovation-in-brazil/17786#sthash.iDTn1tX3.dpuf</ref> The company originated from a merger of two existing Swiss-based marketing companies, CWL and Prisma Sports & Media. Infront's origins are in the football business, but in 2005 the company lost a majority of its FIFA business and subsequently diversified. Today the company is divided into Summer and Winter sports properties (in line with the Olympic differentiation) and also has dedicated Football, Endurance and Digital Production and Sports Solutions units.<ref>{{cite web |author=Adam Nelson |url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/movers_and_shakers/infront_appoints_claude_ruibal |title=Infront appoints Claude Ruibal |publisher=sportspromedia.com |date= |accessdate=2017-02-05}}</ref> Until 2011 it was owned by a consortium of shareholders.{{Citation needed|date=March 2015}} In September 2011 – European private equity firm [[Bridgepoint Capital|Bridgepoint]] reached an agreement to acquire the company.<ref>{{cite web |author=Helia Ebrahimi |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/privateequity/8737752/Bridgepoint-buys-Swiss-sports-rights-company.html |title=Bridgepoint Buys Swiss Sports Rights Company |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-09-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bridgepoint.eu/about-us/news-views/bridgepoint-reaches-agreement-acquire-infront-sports-media-ag|title=Bridgepoint Reaches Agreement to Acquire Infront Sports & Media AG|publisher=Bridgepoint.eu|date=|accessdate=2011-09-05|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927073604/http://www.bridgepoint.eu/about-us/news-views/bridgepoint-reaches-agreement-acquire-infront-sports-media-ag|archivedate=27 September 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=IP/11/1585 |title=Mergers: Commission approves acquisition of sports marketing group Infront by Bridgepoint|publisher=Europa.eu |date= |accessdate=2011-12-20}}</ref>
In February 2015, Chinese conglomerate [[Dalian Wanda]] won an auction to purchase Infront from Bridgepoint for more than €1 billion.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cotterill|first1=Joseph|last2=Massoudi|first2=Arash|last3=Blitz|first3=Roger|title=Dalian Wanda buys Sepp Blatter nephew’s sports rights agency|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/92157ce8-b070-11e4-a2cc-00144feab7de.html|website=Financial Times|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/afp-chinas-wanda-buys-sports-group-infront-for-1.05-bn-euros-2015-2?IR=T|title=Chinas Wanda buys sports group Infront for 1.05 billion euros|publisher=businessinsider.com|date= |accessdate=2015-02-09}}</ref> In November of that same year, it was announced that Infront would merge with the [[World Triathlon Corporation]] (including the latter's Ironman brand) to form the Wanda Sports division.<ref>{{cite web |author=Liam Morgan |url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1032025/infront-sports-media-and-world-triathlon-corporation-to-merge-following-purchase-by-dalian-wanda-group |title=Infront Sports & Media and World Triathlon Corporation to merge following purchase by Dalian Wanda Group|publisher=Inside the games.biz |date= |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref>
==Services== Infront Sports & Media has 900 employees in 35 offices which are operated by several subsidiaries specializing in a geographic region as well as in specialized services.<ref name = fiba1>http://www.fiba.com/news/fiba-joins-forces-with-wanda-to-raise-global-impact-of-basketball "FIBA joins forces with Wanda to raise global impact of basketball" Retrieved February 2, 2017</ref><ref name = infront1>http://www.infrontsports.com/about-infront/ Retrieved February 2, 2017</ref><ref name="liveproduction.tv">{{cite web|url=http://www.live-production.tv/news/sports/fifa-appoints-infront-exclusive-sales-representative-distribution-asian-broadcast-rights|title=FIFA appoints Infront as Exclusive Sales Representative for Asian Broadcast Rights|publisher=liveproduction.tv|date= |accessdate=2010-10-30}}</ref> Infront Sports & Media supports media rights distribution, marketing concepts and sponsorship sales for sporting events as well as media production<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isportconnect.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12330:wtc-to-offer-magazine-programming-for-ironman-series&catid=49:other-sports&Itemid=55 |title=WTC to offer Magazine Programming to Ironman Series|publisher=isportconnect.com|date= |accessdate=2012-06-14}}</ref> (host broadcasting, post production and archive management). An Infront subsidiary, Host Broadcast Services, produces television and radio signals for the [[FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.live-production.tv/news/sports/hbs-towards-start-2010-fifa-world-cup%E2%84%A2.html|title=With HBS towards the start of the 2010 FIFA World Cup|publisher=liveproduction.tv|date= |accessdate=2010-05-03}}</ref> HBS provides a stereo, 5.1, and satellite broadcast feed to organizations that own the rights to the media, typically with 40 minutes of pre-game and 20 minutes of post-game content.<ref name="dakfhj"/> Another Infront subsidiary, Omnigon <ref>{{cite web |author=David Lieberman |url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/wanda-infront-sports-media-build-digital-muscle-buys-omnigon-1201686858/|title=Wanda’s Infront Builds Digital Sports Muscle With Acquisition Of Omnigon|publisher=deadline.com|date= |accessdate=2016-01-20}}</ref> helps sports, media and entertainment providers to develop mobile apps and websites.<ref>{{cite web |author=Dan Palmer |url=http://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1045087/international-ski-federation-launch-new-mobile-app|title=International Ski Federation launch new mobile app|publisher=insidethegames.bi|date= |accessdate=2016-12-21}}</ref>
Infront also provides hospitality and catering,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stadia-magazine.com/news.php?NewsID=13102 |title=Kofler and Infront Hospitality in hospitality business alliance|publisher=stadia-magazine.com}}</ref> stadium advertising,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/sv_sandhausen_names_infront_as_exclusive_marketing_partner/|title=SV Sandhausen names_Infront_as_exclusive_marketing_partner|publisher=stadia-magazine.com|date= |accessdate=2012-07-19}}</ref> event management and other related services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.live-production.tv/news/sports/four-hills-tournament-introduces-single-brand-identity.html|title=Four Hills Tournament introduces single brand identity|publisher=liveproduction.tv|date= |accessdate=2010-11-19}}</ref>
As of May 2018, EHF(European Handball Federation) expands 25-year-long partnership with Infront, runs to 2030.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.infrontsports.com/news/2018/05/ehf-expands-25-year-long-partnership-with-infront/|title=EHF expands 25-year-long partnership with Infront {{!}} Infront Sports & Media AG|website=www.infrontsports.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-01}}</ref>
On June 4, 2018, Infront announced the acquisition of leading European obstacle course event organiser XLETIX GmbH in a move that extends its footprint in the growing personal and corporate fitness sector.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.infrontsports.com/news/2018/06/infront-strengthens-themed-run-portfolio-with-xletix-gmbh-acquisition/|title=Infront strengthens themed run portfolio with XLETIX GmbH acquisition {{!}} Infront Sports & Media AG|website=www.infrontsports.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref>
On July 2018, Infront and FIDAL, the Italian Athletics Federation, announced a six-year partnership on Friday which will run until 2024. The agreement unveiled at a press conference in Rome, will see Infront and FIDAL collaborate at all levels of the federation's events and projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.infrontsports.com/news/2018/07/running-to-future-infront-adds-athletics-to-italian-portfolio-with-fidal-partnership/?utm_content=74906542&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter|title=Running to future: Infront adds Athletics to Italian portfolio with FIDAL partnership}}</ref>
==Notable work== Infront Sports & Media represents all seven Olympic winter sport federations,<ref>{{cite web |author=David Cushnan|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/eurosport_renews_major_winter_sports_package/|title=Eurosport Renews Major Winter Sports Package|publisher=sportspromedia.com|date= |accessdate=2012-02-16}}</ref> including the [[IIHF]] for ice hockey<ref>{{cite web |author=Adam Fraser|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/infront_signs_shkoda_to_record-breaking_iihf_deal/ |title=Infront Signs Skoda to Record Breaking IIHF Deal|publisher=sportspromedia.com|date= |accessdate=2011-05-16}}</ref> and the IBU for biathlon. It also manages media and/or marketing rights to most of the [[FIS Alpine Ski World Cup|FIS World Cup]] events.<ref>{{cite web |author=David Cushnan | url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/infront_re_ups_with_finnish_ski_association_for_nordic_rights/ |title=Infront re-ups with Finnish Ski Association |publisher=sportspromedia.com|date= |accessdate=2013-01-11}}</ref> In summer sports, Infront started supporting mass participation and endurance sports in 2011, including [[Ironman Triathlon|Ironman]] events<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.isportconnect.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=8626:world-triathlon-corporation-partner-with-infront-to-attract-sponsors&catid=9:sports-marketing&Itemid=19 |title=World Triathlon Corporation Partner with Infront to Attract Sponsors |publisher=isportconnect.com|date= |accessdate=2011-10-07}}</ref> and the [[Union Cycliste Internationale|UCI]] World Championships in cycling.<ref>{{cite web |author=James Emmett|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/news/uci_set_for_commercial_growth_after_landmark_infront_deal/ |title=UCI Set for Commercial Growth after Infront landmark deal|publisher=sportspromedia.com|date= |accessdate=2012-09-20}}</ref> It is also a partner for the [[European Handball Federation|EHF EURO]] in handball<ref>{{cite web|author=Adam Fraser|url=http://www.sportspromedia.com/notes_and_insights/handball_is_big_business_across_europe/|title=Handball is Big Business Across Europe|publisher=sportspromedia.com|date=|accessdate=2009-12-11}}</ref> and the CEV European Championships in Volleyball. In China, Infront represents the [[Chinese Basketball Association]] tournament and the national team, Team China Basketball.<ref>{{cite web |author=Matt Cutler |url=http://www.sportbusiness.com/news/186240/infront-to-continue-forward-momentum-of-chinese-basketball|title=Infront to Continue Forward Momentum of Chinese Basketball|publisher=sportsbusiness.com|date= |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Sun Xiaochen |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/sports/incheonasiangames/2014-09/16/content_18614968.htm|title=Sponsors confident in future of basketball league|publisher=chinadaily.com.cn|date= |accessdate=2014-09-16}}</ref> Infront's HBS subsidiary was awarded the Judge's award at the 2010 International Broadcasting Convention for its work helping FIFA broadcast the World Cup in stereoscopic 3D.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.live-production.tv/case-studies/sports/3d-production-fifa-world-cup%E2%84%A2-2010.html |title=3D Production: FIFA World Cup™ 2010|publisher=liveproduction.tv|date= |accessdate=2010-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibc.org/page.cfm/link=330|title=2010 Judges Prize|publisher=www.ibc.org|date= |accessdate=2010}}</ref>
In football, Infront has supported the FIFA World Cup since 2002. It distributes the Asian media rights and manages the host broadcast production.<ref name="liveproduction.tv"/> In 2011, Transparency International asked Fifa to be more open about possible conflicts of interest, when it was discovered that the President of Infront was Philippe Blatter, nephew to the President of Fifa, [[Sepp Blatter]]. Fifa said Blatter was not involved in awarding the deal to Infront.<ref>{{cite web |author=David Bond|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15497214 |title=Fifa criticised after TV rights handed to Sepp Blatter's nephew|publisher=bbc.co.uk|date= |accessdate=2011-10-28}}</ref> Infront also works with the [[German Football Association]] (DFB),<ref>{{cite web |author=Matt Cutler |url=http://www.sportbusiness.com/news/184850/dfb-expands-infront-media-rights-partnership|title=DFB Expands Infront Media Rights Partnership|publisher=sportsbusiness.com |date=|accessdate=2011-12-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author= Paul Nicholson |url=http://www.insideworldfootball.com/world-football/europe/15267-infront-secure-four-more-years-to-their-package-of-german-sales-rights|title=Infront secures four more years to their package of German sales rights|publisher=insideworldfootball.com |date=|accessdate=2014-08-18}}</ref> the Italian [[Lega Serie A]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportelmonaco.com/hot_news.en.htm?newsid=28 |title=Football made in Italy|publisher=sportelmonaco.com|date= |accessdate=2009-10-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/11/18/uk-italy-soccer-infront-idUKBRE9AH0W920131118|title=Italy football clubs pick adviser for TV rights negotiations|publisher=uk.reuters.com|date= |accessdate=2013-11-18}}</ref> and the Indonesian, [[Indonesia Super League]].<ref>{{cite web|title=ISL Musim 2015 Tak Bisa Lagi Disaksikan Melalui Antena UHF|url=http://www.bolaindo.com/2014/12/09/isl-musim-2015-tak-bisa-lagi-disaksikan-melalui-antena-uhf/|accessdate=18 January 2015|language=Indonesian}}</ref> In 2016 Infront with Omnigon collaborated on several projects including digital services to the Serie A and mobile app development for the German Football Association’s DFB Cup.<ref name = Deadline1>http://deadline.com/2016/01/wanda-infront-sports-media-build-digital-muscle-buys-omnigon-1201686858/ Wanda’s Infront Builds Digital Sports Muscle With Acquisition Of Omnigon by David Lieberman January 20th, 2016 Retrieved February 9th, 2017</ref><ref name =sportsbusinessdaily1>http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Daily/Issues/2016/01/20/Finance/Infront.aspx Infront Sports & Media Acquires Controlling 51% Equity Interest In Omnigon Januarth 20th, 2016 Retrieved February 9th, 2017</ref>

{{Infobox national basketball team | country = {{IRI}} | type = Women's Youth | logo = | logo_width = 200px | FIBA_ranking = not ranked
as of 10 December 2016 | joined_FIBA = 2000 | FIBA_zone = FIBA Asia | national_fed = [[Islamic Republic of Iran Basketball Federation]] (I.R.I.B.F.) | first_game = {{bkwu|17|NEP}} 32–'''89''' '''{{bkwu-rt|17|IRI}}'''
[[2017 FIBA Under-16 Women's Asian Championship]]
([[Bangalore]], India; 23 October 2017) | coach = Elaheh Darestani (2017) | medal_templates = | wc_championship = [[FIBA Under-17 Women’s Basketball World Cup|Under-17 Women's World Cup]] | wc_appearances = None | wc_medals = None | zone_championship = [[FIBA Asia Under-16 Championship for Women|Under-16 Women's Asian Championship]] | zone_appearances = 1 | zone_medals = None }} The '''Iran women's national under-16 and under-17 basketball team''' is the national [[basketball]] team of [[Iran]] for Junior Women, governed by the [[Islamic Republic of Iran Basketball Federation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fiba.basketball/federation/Iran|title=Iran Profile Page|publisher=[[FIBA]]|accessdate=19 October 2018}} It represents the country in international under-16 and under-17 women's basketball competitions. The team participated for the first time during the [[2017 FIBA Under-16 Women's Asian Championship]] in [[India]], wherein they finished fourth in Division B. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{IranNationalTeams}} {{International basketball (Women)}} {{FIBA Asia women's teams}} [[Category:Women's national under-17 basketball teams]] [[Category:Women's national sports teams of Iran|Basketball]] {{Iran-sport-stub}} {{Basketball-team-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | name = July 5 Stadium
ملعب 5 جويلية
Stade du 5 Juillet | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Stade 5 Juillet 1962.jpg | image_upright = 1.2 | caption = | fullname = July 5, 1962 Stadium | former_names = | location = Route du 5 Juillet
[[Algiers]], [[Algeria]] | coordinates = {{Coord|36|45|35.60|N|2|59|42.70|E|region:DZ_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1970 | opened = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|1972|6|17}} | renovated = 1999, 2003, 2008, 2015, 2017 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Ministry of Youth and Sport | operator = | surface = AirFibr hybrid grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 64,000 | suites = | record_attendance = {{formatnum: 110,000}} [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]]-[[Serbia national football team|Serbia]]
(3 March 2010) | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[MC Alger]]
[[USM Alger]]
[[Algeria national football team]] }} '''July 5, 1962 Stadium''' ({{Lang-en|5 July 1962 Stadium}}, {{Lang-ar|ملعب 5 جويلية 1962}}), (the name refers to 5 July 1962, the day [[Algeria]] declared independence from France), also known as '''El Djezair Stadium''' ({{Lang-ar|ملعب 5 جويلية بالجزائر}}), is a [[association football|football]] and [[track and field|athletics]] stadium located in [[Algiers]], [[Algeria]]. The stadium was inaugurated in 1972 with a capacity of 95,000. It served as the main stadium of the [[1975 Mediterranean Games]], the [[1978 All-Africa Games]], the [[2004 Pan Arab Games]], and the [[2007 All-Africa Games]]. The stadium was one of two venues of the [[1990 African Cup of Nations]] (the other venue was the [[Stade 19 Mai 1956]] in [[Annaba]]). It hosted 9 matches of the tournament, including the final match, which had a second record attendance of 105,302 spectators. In the final match, the home team Algeria defeated Nigeria 1-0 to win the tournament. The record attendance is of 110,000 spectators in the frendly match between Algeria and Serbia on 3 March 2010.{{cite news|url=http://www.lemidi-dz.com/index.php?operation=voir_article&id_article=sport%40art6%402010-03-06 |title=110.000 spectateurs au stade du 5-juillet |publisher=Le Midi |accessdate=6 March 2010 |date= }} It also hosted the [[2000 African Championships in Athletics]]. After a formal compliance with current safety standards in 1999, the stadium was reduced to an 80,200 capacity, and following a new phase of renovation in 2003, the stadium's capacity has been reduced further to its current all-seater capacity of 64,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.elbilad.net/article/detail?id=13119 |title=Stade 5 Juillet 1962 |publisher=Algerie Presse Service |date= |accessdate=2014-07-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714162605/http://www.elbilad.net/article/detail?id=13119 |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }} The future capacity will be 80,000 with possible further renovations.{{cite web|url=http://www.dzfoot.com/2015/02/09/stades-sellal-relance-lagrandissement-du-5-juillet-62560.php |title=Stades : Sellal relance l’agrandissement du 5 juillet|publisher=dzfoot.com |date=9 February 2015 |accessdate= 16 April 2015}} == History == Opened in 1972 by President [[Houari Boumediene]], it is home then the first tournament international networking selection Maghreb with players such qu'Allal, Filali, Bamous, Faras, Lalmas, Guedioura, Chekroun, the [[AC Milan]] with the Prati Albertosi, the Brazilian club Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras with the famous Ademir da Guia. The White Pele before [[Zico]], and the Spanish club of [[Valencia CF|Valencia]]. It also [[Nacer Guedioura]], father of the current Algerian international [[Adlène Guedioura]] who is the author of the first goal Official of this legendary stadium during the final Cup of Algeria opposed the junior [[USM Alger]] to [[RC Kouba]] and which ended with a score of 1-0 for the [[USM Alger]]. Then follow the [[Mediterranean Games|Games Mediterranean]], which are organized in 1975, the stadium had a capacity of {{formatnum:110000}} seats. But the record attendance was achieved in 1990, when the final of the [[1990 African Cup of Nations|African Cup of Nations]], which contrasts the [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] and [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] (1-0), with {{formatnum:105302}} spectators. After compliance with current safety standards [[1999 in sports|1999]], the stadium is reduced to {{formatnum:80200}} places around, and following a new phase of renovation in [[2003 in sports|2003]], the capacity is further reduced to {{formatnum:76200}} seats. In 2008, Stade 5 Juillet 1962 once again experienced work, which shall include installation by Queens Grass Netherlands company to a new lawn and renovation of the stadium infrastructure. The works ended in the month of August 2009. The soccer friendly match between the national football teams of [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] and [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] was held on August 12, 2009 on the occasion of the reopening of the stadium. The Algerians with a record of final {{Formatnum:110000}} spectators during the friendly match [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]]–[[Serbia national football team|Serbia]] (lost 0-3, March 3, 2010). This is the first game of the Algerian national team since its qualification for the 2010 World Cup obtained in Sudan. In March 2015, the natural sport turf has been replaced by the [[hybrid grass]] technology [http://www.naturalgrass.com/en/realisations/stade-du-5-juillet-1962-algiers/ AirFibr]. == History of the stadium == === Opening the stadium === After the independence of Algeria, Algeria was very popular for football, especially as it was associated with the sacrifices of Algerians in the glorious liberation revolution and the sacrifices of the FLN players with wealth, money and fame in the finest French clubs in exchange for forming a team representing Algeria in tournaments and demonstrations. The construction of a large stadium in Algeria was an encouraging step for football and a step towards its support after independence by the late President [[Houari Boumediene]]. The date of the launching of the works during 1970 and the work lasted two years. The stadium was opened on 17 June 1972 with a speech by President [[Houari Boumedienne]] in a friendly tournament involving 4 teams: the Arab Maghreb, [[AC Milan]], [[Hungary]] and [[Palmeiras]]. The first goal of the stadium was for the Moroccan player Filali for the Maghreb team against Hungary, as the first official game on the pitch was the final of the [[Cup of Algeria]] 1972 between the two teams of the capital [[USM Alger]] and [[Hamra Annaba]] was the first official goal of the stadium to the [[Hamra Annaba]] player Tadjet where he won the meeting and the cup,as for the first game for the Algerian team on the pitch was in front of the Turkish team and won the Algerian team 1-0. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.goalzz.com/main.aspx?showstadiums=1&searchcountry=DZ&stadium=362 Stade 5 Juillet 1962 - ''goalzz.com''] * [http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/africa/algeria/algiers_national.shtml Stadium information - ''worldstadiums.com''] {{S-start}} {{Succession box| title=[[Mediterranean Games]]

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Karşıyaka Arena | image = File:Karsiyaka-arena.jpg | image_size = 300px | location = [[Karşıyaka]], [[İzmir]], [[Turkey]] | coordinates = {{coord|38.47448|N|27.07678|E|type:landmark_scale:3000|display=inline,title}} | demolished = | opened = {{start date and age|2005}} | owner = [[Karşıyaka SK|Karşıyaka Spor Kulübü]] | operator = Karşıyaka Municipality | acreage = {{convert|11650|m2|ft2|abbr=on}} | construction_cost = | former_names = | tenants = [[Pınar Karşıyaka]] - Basketball,
[[Karşıyaka Women's Volleyball Team]] - Volleyball | seating_capacity = 5,200 (upper tier only)
6,500 (with lower tier) | Official_website = }} '''Karşıyaka Arena''' (also known as '''Mustafa Kemal Atatürk Karşıyaka Sport Hall''') is a multi-purpose [[indoor arena]] that is located in [[İzmir]], [[Turkey]]. It was opened in 2005. It is owned and run by [[Karşıyaka SK]]. The 6,500 seating capacity arena is used mostly to host [[basketball]] and [[volleyball]] games, as well as [[concert]]s and [[Ceremony|events]]. The arena also features a VIP lounge area with seating for 90, an additional practice training hall that seats 500 people, a weight training room, fitness and aerobics facilities, a conference room that holds 100 people, a media room for the press, a medical room, locker room facilities, 20 athlete guesthouses, cafeterias, administrative offices, a sports bar, and 800 parking spaces. ==History== Karşıyaka Arena was built for the [[2005 Summer Universiade]], where it hosted [[Basketball at the 2005 Summer Universiade|2005 Summer Universiade Basketball]] and [[Volleyball at the 2005 Summer Universiade|2005 Summer Universiade Volleyball]]. The arena was used to host the [[EuroChallenge]] [[EuroChallenge 2012–13|2012–13 season's]] [[2013 FIBA EuroChallenge Final Four|Final Four tournament]], where the tournament's home team, [[Pınar Karşıyaka]], lost in the final to [[BC Krasnye Krylia|Krasnye Krylia]]. ==External links== *[http://www.kskbasketbol.net/v2/grafik/icerik/karsiyaka_arena.jpg Exterior Image of Karşıyaka Arena] *[http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-t9A6OU-afkU/TqMX5xyAzbI/AAAAAAAAAck/ToMv-RkaJ2U/s1600/SDC13635.JPG Interior Image 1 of Karşıyaka Arena] *[http://karsiyaka.bel.tr/Files/images/Tesisler/spor/arena/karsiyaka_arena.JPG Interior Image 2 of Karşıyaka Arena] *[http://www.renklikutu.net/uploads/8/1/8/4/8184618/2659240_orig.jpg Interior Image 3 of Karşıyaka Arena] {{Karşıyaka S.K.}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Karsiyaka Arena}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish Basketball League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Izmir]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Turkey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2005]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 2005]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = League of Denial | image = League_of_denial.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | authors = {{unbulleted list|[[Mark Fainaru-Wada]]|[[Steve Fainaru]]}} | country = | language = English | subject = | genre = | publisher = [[Crown Archetype]] | pub_date = October 8, 2013 | published = | media_type = | pages = 416 | awards = | isbn = 978-0770437541 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }} '''''League of Denial''''' is a 2013 book, initially broadcast as a documentary film, about [[traumatic brain injury]] in the [[National Football League]] (NFL), particularly [[concussions in American football|concussions]] and [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]] (CTE). The documentary, entitled ''League of Denial: The NFL's Concussion Crisis'', was produced by ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' and broadcast on [[PBS]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Fainaru|first=Mark|title=When It Comes To Brain Injury, Authors Say NFL Is In A 'League Of Denial'|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/10/07/229181970/when-it-comes-to-brain-injury-authors-say-nfl-is-in-a-league-of-denial|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=September 28, 2002|accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wolfley|first=Bob|title=Much of Frontline's 'League of Denial' documentary rests on the case of Mike Webster|url=http://www.jsonline.com/blogs/sports/226368231.html|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date=October 3, 2013|accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lowry|first=Brian|title="League of Denial: The NFL’s Concussion Crisis," "Schooled" TV Reviews|url=https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/frontlines-league-of-denial-the-nfls-concussion-crisis-epixs-schooled-the-price-of-college-sports-tv-reviews-1200688922/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=October 6, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Gregory |first=Sean|title=League Of Denial Documents The NFL's Concussion Failures|url=http://keepingscore.blogs.time.com/2013/10/07/new-book-and-pbs-documentary-details-nfls-concussion-denial/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=October 7, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Don Van Natta, Jr.|title=New book, "League of Denial," says NFL used its resources and power over two decades to deny football link to brain damage|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/otl/story/_/id/9745797/new-book-league-denial-says-nfl-used-resources-power-two-decades-deny-football-link-brain-damage|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=October 2, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Slothower |first=Jen|title='League of Denial' Shows NFL Ignoring Concussion Evidence, Mike Webster’s Fall, Roger Goodell Digging In|url=http://nesn.com/2013/10/league-of-denial-shows-nfl-ignoring-concussion-evidence-mike-websters-fall-roger-goodell-digging-in/|publisher=[[New England Sports Network]]|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> The book was written by [[ESPN]] reporters [[Mark Fainaru-Wada]] and [[Steve Fainaru]]. The book and film devote significant attention to the story of [[Mike Webster]] and his football-related brain injuries, and the pathologist who examined Webster's brain, [[Bennet Omalu]]. The film also looks closely at the efforts of researchers led by [[Ann McKee]] at [[Boston University]]'s Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, where the brains of a number of former NFL athletes have been examined.<ref name=Chittum>{{cite news|last=Chittum|first=Ryan|title=Frontline's landmark 'League of Denial' |url=http://www.cjr.org/the_audit/frontlines_landmark_league_of.php|accessdate=9 October 2013|newspaper=Columbia Journalism Review|date=9 October 2013}}</ref> ==Production== [[File:Steve Fainaru & Mark Fainaru-Wada at 2014 Peabody Awards (cropped).jpg|thumb|Brothers [[Steve Fainaru]] (left) and [[Mark Fainaru-Wada]], co-authors of the book ]] [[ESPN]] had originally been a partner in the project, but backed out later<ref>[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/sports/league-of-denial/a-note-from-frontline-espn-and-league-of-denial/ A Note from FRONTLINE: ESPN and “League of Denial”]</ref> claiming a lack of editorial control. There was speculation that this was due to pressure from the NFL.<ref>{{cite web|author=Erik Malinowski |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/erikmalinowski/weve-seen-frontlines-highly-anticipated-concussion-documenta |title=We've Seen Frontline's Highly Anticipated Concussion Documentary, And It Is Very Bad For The NFL |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|date=October 7, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=James Andrew Miller|author2=Ken Belson|title=N.F.L. Pressure Said to Lead ESPN to Quit Film Project|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/24/sports/football/nfl-pressure-said-to-prompt-espn-to-quit-film-project.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=August 23, 2013|accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref> Although ESPN pulled out of the documentary project, they remain involved in the book deal, including promoting the book on their website,<ref>{{cite web|author=John Koblin|url=http://deadspin.com/espn-gets-back-into-the-league-of-denial-game-sorta-1440202980|title=ESPN Gets Back Into The League Of Denial Game (Sorta)|publisher=[[Deadspin]]|date=October 2, 2013|accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref> and airing excerpts from the documentary on the program ''[[Outside the Lines]]''. <ref name=newrepublic>{{cite web|author=Marc Tracy|title=We Are All to Blame for the NFL's Concussion Crisis|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/115067/frontline-league-denial-review-nfl-concussion-crisis-ours-too|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
During the documentary, Omalu recalled a discussion with an NFL doctor while reviewing Webster's case. Omalu said the NFL doctor told him "Bennett, do you know the implications of what you're doing? If 10 percent of mothers in this country would begin to perceive football as a dangerous sport, that is the end of football."<ref>{{cite web|last=Brinson|first=Will|title=Frontline PBS doc 'League of Denial' examines NFL concussion problem|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/24051122/frontline-pbs-doc-league-of-denial-examines-nfl-concussion-problem|publisher=[[CBS Sports]]|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> ''Frontline'' in 2010 produced a documentary on [[health issues in youth sports]] with a focus on repeated concussions and subconcussive blows in high school football.<ref>{{cite web|title=Football High|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/football-high/|publisher=[[PBS]]|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
The documentary received a [[Peabody Award]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=FRONTLINE: League of Denial: The NFL’s Concussion Crisis (PBS)|url=http://www.peabodyawards.com/award-profile/frontline-league-of-denial-the-nfls-concussion-crisis-pbs|publisher=[[Peabody Award]]s|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
==Critical response==
Response to the documentary was positive, with many reviewers commenting on how powerful it was, and how it may change their views of football going forward, although noting that much of the information had been written about or shown before.<ref>{{cite web|last=Katzowitz|first=Josh|title=Reactions to the Frontline PBS documentary, 'League of Denial'|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nfl/eye-on-football/24052263/reactions-to-the-frontline-pbs-documentary-league-of-denial|publisher=CBS Sports|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> [[File:The crew of FRONTLINE-League of Denial at the 73rd Annual Peabody Awards.jpg|thumb|left|Lauren Ezell, Colette Neirouz Hanna, Mark Fainaru-Wada, Steve Fainaru, Steve Audette, Jim Gilmore, David Fanning, and Michael Kirk accept the Peabody Award for "Frontline: League of Denial: The NFL's Concussion Crisis"]] Michael Humphrey from ''[[Forbes]]'' wrote that "to deny the implications of the show and not, at the very least, take that potential hypocrisy very seriously, would be delusional. If I keep watching [football], it is at my own ethical risk. And I honestly don’t know what I’m going to do."<ref>{{cite news|last=Humphrey |first=Michael|title=What Is The NFL Fan To Do After Frontline's 'League of Denial?'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/michaelhumphrey/2013/10/08/what-is-the-nfl-fan-to-do-after-frontlines-league-of-denial/|work=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> ''[[The New Republic]]'' wrote that "There is not a ton of brand-new such evidence in the documentary" but that "What is groundbreaking about League of Denial, rather, is the cleanness, coherence, and conciseness of the storytelling".<ref name=newrepublic /> The ''[[New York Daily News]]'' said "The only problem with the much-touted ''Frontline'' investigative report ''League of Denial'' is that it probably should have been subtitled "Nation of Denial." Kevin McFarland of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' wrote "League Of Denial provides an excellent, mandatory two-hour overview of the rise in research on this subject." and "Football is a dead sport walking in the United States. It may look healthy, vibrant, and more profitable than ever. But in a few generations it will be a flimsy husk of itself at its height. The damning evidence is all here in League Of Denial."<ref>{{cite web|last=McFarland|first=Kevin|title=Frontline: “League Of Denial: The NFL’s Concussion Crisis”|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/league-of-denial-the-nfls-concussion-crisis,103868/|publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]''|date=October 9, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> ''[[USA Today]]'' wrote "if this documentary made even a sliver of the league's fans, personnel and fellow media stop and reflect for a few hours Tuesday night, it was well worth the exercise."<ref>{{cite news|last=Strauss|first=Chris|title='League of Denial' likely won't change a thing|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2013/10/league-of-denial-frontline-pbs-morning-win/|work=[[USA Today]]|date=October 9, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
''[[The New York Times]]'' said "The program doesn't give the league much credit for recent rule changes and other safety initiatives, instead underscoring its continuing reluctance to acknowledge a link between the sport and brain injuries and its reliance on language that pushes any day of reckoning into the future." and "Much of this has already been reported, with [[Alan Schwarz]] of ''The New York Times'' often leading the way, but the program will certainly be eye-opening for anyone—especially parents with children of Pop Warner league age—who hasn't followed the subject closely or seen ''The United States of Football'', a documentary released in August."<ref>{{cite news|last=Genzlinger|first=Neil|title='League of Denial' Looks at N.F.L. and Concussions|url=http://tv.nytimes.com/2013/10/08/arts/television/league-of-denial-looks-at-nfl-and-concussions.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=October 7, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
NFL senior vice president of health and safety policy Jeff Miller said "[for two decades the league has been a] leader in addressing the issue of head injuries in a serious way" and "By any standard, the NFL has made a profound commitment to the health and safety of its players that can be seen in every aspect of the game, and the results have been both meaningful and measurable."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mihoces|first=Gary|title=Documentary: For years, NFL ignored concussion evidence |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/2013/10/07/frontline-documentary-nfl-concussions/2939747/|work=USA Today|date=October 7, 2013|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Head Games (film)|Head Games]]'', documentary and book by [[Christopher Nowinski]] on repeated trauma in [[contact sport]] * [[Concussions in sport]] * [[Dementia pugilistica]] * [[Helmet-to-helmet collision]] * ''[[Concussion (2015 film)|Concussion]]''
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/league-of-denial/ ''Frontline'': "League of Denial: The NFL's Concussion Crisis"] PBS site for the documentary, where it can be viewed for free. * {{IMDb title|3013938|League of Denial: The NFL's Concussion Crisis}}
