revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=July 2015}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Murrayfield Stadium | nickname = Murrayfield | logo_image = [[File:Murrayfield Stadium logo.svg|200px]] | image = [[File:Murrayfield Stadium 2005-05-13.jpg|300px|Murrayfield]] | caption = | fullname = | location = [[Murrayfield]]
[[Edinburgh]]
EH12 5PJ | coordinates = {{coord|55|56|32|N|3|14|27|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | built = | opened = 1925 | renovated = 1995 | owner = [[Scottish Rugby Union]] | operator = Scottish Rugby Union | surface = [[Under-soil heating|Underheated]] [[Lawn|Grass]] | construction_cost = | architect = Connor Milligan | tenants = [[Scottish Rugby Union]]
[[Edinburgh Rugby]] (1996–2017)
[[Edinburgh Sevens]] (2007–2011)
[[Scottish Claymores]] (1995–2002) | seating_capacity = 67,144 | record_attendance = 104,000 ([[1975 Five Nations Championship|1975 Five Nations]] - [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] vs [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]) | dimensions = |publictransit = [[Haymarket railway station]] [[Murrayfield Stadium tram stop]] }} '''Murrayfield Stadium''' is a sports [[stadium]] located in the west end of [[Edinburgh]], the capital of [[Scotland]]. Its all-seater capacity is 67,144 which makes it the largest stadium in Scotland and the fifth largest in the [[United Kingdom]]. The stadium is the home of the [[Scottish Rugby Union]] (SRU), and is primarily used as a venue for [[rugby union]] and hosts most of [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland's]] home test matches, the ''Scottish Hydro Electric Cup'' final, as well as [[Pro14]] and [[European Rugby Champions Cup]] matches. Although mainly a rugby union stadium, Murrayfield has in the past hosted [[American football]], [[Challenge Cup|rugby league]] and [[association football]] matches and music concerts. ==Location== Murrayfield is located near to [[Murrayfield Ice Rink]], Murrayfield Curling Rink, and close to [[Edinburgh Zoo]]. It is named after the area of Edinburgh it is located in, [[Murrayfield]]. [[File:Murrayfield Autumn 2017.jpg|thumb|300x300px|Murrayfield, the home of Scottish rugby union.Calum Langdale 2018]] == Transport == === Rail === Despite the line running adjacent to the stadium, the closest railway station to the stadium is [[Haymarket railway station|Haymarket]], which lies a mile to the East. Interchange with the [[Edinburgh Trams]] is available at Haymarket and Edinburgh Park. [[Edinburgh Waverley railway station|Edinburgh Waverley station]] is a short walk from the [[St Andrew Square, Edinburgh|St Andrew Square]] tram stop. === Tram === [[Murrayfield Stadium tram stop]] is located close to the turnstiles on [[Roseburn|Roseburn Street]]. Access to the platform is by a flight of stairs. As part of crowd-management measures, ticketing machines are situated at the bottom of the staircase and not the platform. {{s-rail-start|noclear=yes}} {{s-rail|title=Edinburgh Trams}} {{Rail line|previous=[[Haymarket railway station|Haymarket]]
''towards [[York Place tram stop|York Place]]'' |next=[[Balgreen]]
''towards [[Edinburgh Airport tram stop|Airport]]''|route=''York Place - Edinburgh Airport''|col={{temporary rail colour|8D122A}} }} {{s-end}} === Buses === The stadium is served by [[Lothian Buses|Lothian Bus]] services 12, 22, 26, 31 and the Airlink(100) along Corstorphine Road.{{cite web |url=https://lothianbuses.co.uk/assets/files/Murrayfield-east-lb.pdf |title=Getting to BT Murrayfield from Edinburgh City Centre |publisher=[[Lothian Buses]] |accessdate=22 October 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://lothianbuses.co.uk/assets/files/Murrayfield-west-lb.pdf |title=Getting to BT Murrayfield from Edinburgh Airport and Ingliston or Hermiston Park & Ride |publisher=[[Lothian Buses]] |accessdate=22 October 2017}} Post-match traffic congestion is common along this route. ==History== {{expand section|date=May 2014}} The SRU identified 19 acres of land at Murrayfield, purchasing this from Edinburgh Polo Club at Murrayfield, having raised money through [[Debenture_(sport)| debentures]].{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12541855.Changed_days_as_the_home_of_Scottish_rugby_takes_on_world_of_big_business_From_cricket_pitch_to_a_cash_____________jackpot/ |title=Changed days as the home of Scottish rugby takes on world of big business From cricket pitch to a cash jackpot |work=The Herald |date=4 March 1995 |accessdate=14 January 2016}} A stand and three embankments were constructed, which took two years. Previous internationals had been played at [[Inverleith]].{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/heritage/people-places/scottish-flashback-murrayfield-in-the-snow-1963-1-3672534 |title=Scottish Flashback: Murrayfield in the snow, 1963 |work=The Scotsman |date=28 January 2015 |accessdate=13 December 2015}} On 21 March 1925 {{nrut|England}} were the first team to visit Murrayfield, with 70,000 people watching {{nrut|Scotland}} beat them to win their first [[Five Nations Championship]] [[Grand Slam (Rugby Union)|Grand Slam]]. During the [[Second World War]] the ground at Murrayfield was offered to the nation and was taken over by the [[Royal Army Service Corps]] and used as a supply depot. During the war years the [[British armed forces|armed forces]] sports authorities managed to arrange two Scotland v. England services internationals each year, on a home-and-away basis. Scotland's home matches were played at Inverleith for the first two years with a return to Murrayfield in 1944 after that ground's derequisition. Murrayfield's record attendance of 104,000 was set on 1 March 1975 when Scotland defeated {{nrut|Wales}} 12–10 during the [[1975 Five Nations Championship]].{{cite web |url=https://canmore.org.uk/site/73600/edinburgh-roseburn-street-murrayfield-stadium |title=Edinburgh, Roseburn Street, Murrayfield Stadium |work=[[Canmore (database)|Canmore]] |publisher=[[Historic Environment Scotland]] |accessdate=13 December 2015}} This attendance stood as a world record until 1999. The East stand was built in 1983.{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12685727.How_Murrayfield_is_growing_great/ |title=How Murrayfield is growing great |work=The Herald |date=5 February 1994|accessdate=19 November 2017}} In October 1991 another debenture scheme was launched, to finance a more comprehensive redevelopment of the West Stand.{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12685828.The_debenture_scheme_delivers_delight/ |title=The debenture scheme delivers delight |work=The Herald |date=5 February 1994 |accessdate=14 January 2016}} The new West Stand was designed with a 48-metre cantilever roof.{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12626927.Murrayfield_is_entering_a_bright_new_era/ |title=Murrayfield is entering a bright new era |work=The Herald |date=13 January 1993 |accessdate=30 October 2017}} The old West Stand housed a museum, but this was not replaced and plans for a new visitor centre were shelved when the game turned professional.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/return-of-murrayfield-museum-remains-beyond-sru-s-pocket-1-817699 |title=Return of Murrayfield museum remains beyond SRU's pocket |work=The Scotsman |date=16 July 2010 |accessdate=29 October 2017}} The first phase was completed in January 1993 with the new north and south stands opening. In February 1994 the centre section of the new West Stand opened. In 1994, Murrayfield completed a £50-million renovation where floodlights were installed for the first time. In October 2012, SRU chief executive Mark Dodson told the BBC that it was actively seeking a name sponsor for Murrayfield:{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-union/20128230 |title=Murrayfield could be renamed for right price – Scottish Rugby |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=29 October 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2012}}
The single biggest piece of our inventory is our national stadium. We would like to see if we can monetise that. It would be crazy for us not to look at using our single biggest piece of inventory to drive revenue. We want to get the right price for it.
In addition, Dodson indicated that the SRU was actively seeking a site for a completely new stadium with a capacity of 10,000 to 15,000 as a future home for Edinburgh Rugby.{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/rugby/top-rugby-stories/sru-chiefs-seek-murrayfield-stadium-name-change-sponsor-to-help-pay-off-debts-1-2604968 |title=SRU chiefs seek Murrayfield stadium name change sponsor to help pay off debts |newspaper=[[The Scotsman]] |date=30 October 2012 |accessdate=30 October 2012}} The pitch was damaged by [[nematode]]s in the lead up to the 2013 autumn internationals. This led the SRU to replace the grass with a [[Desso GrassMaster|Desso surface]] from the start of the 2014 season.{{cite news|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/sports/393290/scots-to-install-hybrid-pitch-at-murrayfield|title=Scots to install hybrid pitch at Murrayfield|work=Bangkok Post}} A naming rights deal with [[British Telecom|BT]] was agreed in May 2014, resulting in the stadium being officially named as the BT Murrayfield Stadium.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-union/27605156 |title=Scottish Rugby confirms deal for BT Murrayfield Stadium |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=28 May 2014 |accessdate=28 May 2014}} ==Uses== ===Rugby union=== [[File:MurrayfieldStadium2002.jpg|thumb|right|Murrayfield Stadium in 2002.]] [[File:MurrayfieldRugbyWorldCup.JPG|thumb|right]] Murrayfield is used for most [[Scotland|Scottish]] international [[rugby union]] matches, with all Scotland's [[Six Nations Championship|Six Nations]] home games being played in the stadium. The stadium also hosted all of [[Edinburgh Rugby|Edinburgh's]] matches between 1996 and January 2017. (For Pro14 matches, only the lower tier of the West Stand is typically used.) Since January 2017 only selected Edinburgh matches are held at Murrayfield. From [[2006–07 IRB Sevens World Series|2007]] to [[2010–11 IRB Sevens World Series|2011]], Murrayfield hosted the [[Edinburgh Sevens|Edinburgh 7s]], then the final event in the annual [[IRB Sevens World Series]] in [[rugby sevens]], but that tournament was moved to [[Glasgow]] starting in [[2011–12 IRB Sevens World Series|2012]] due to low attendance. Murrayfield hosted select matches from the [[2007 Rugby World Cup]]. The stadium also hosted the [[Heineken Cup]] Final in [[2004–05 Heineken Cup|2005]], when [[Stade Toulousain|Toulouse]] beat [[Stade Français]] 18–12, and again in [[2008–09 Heineken Cup|2009]], with Leinster defeating Leicester 19–16.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/8057916.stm |title=Leicester 16–19 Leinster |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 May 2008}} ====Rugby World Cup==== Murrayfield hosted matches of the [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991]], [[1999 Rugby World Cup|1999]] and [[2007 Rugby World Cup|2007]] [[Rugby World Cup]]s. =====1991===== {|class="wikitable" ! Date ! Competition !colspan=2| Home team !colspan=2| Away team ! Attendance |- |5 October 1991 || [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool 2 || {{ru|SCO}} || 47 || {{ru|JPN}} || 9 || 40,000 |- |9 October 1991 || [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool 2 || {{ru|SCO}} || 51 || {{ru|ZIM}} || 12 || 35,000 |- |12 October 1991 || [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool 2 || {{ru|SCO}} || 24 || {{Ru|IRE}} || 15 || 54,000 |- |19 October 1991 || [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Quarter-final 2 || {{Ru|SCO}} || 28 || {{ru|SAM|name=Western Samoa}} || 6 || 54,000 |- |26 October 1991 || [[1991 Rugby World Cup|1991]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Semi-final 1 || {{Ru|SCO}} || 6 || {{Ru|ENG}} || 9 || 54,000 |} =====1999===== {|class="wikitable" ! Date ! Competition !colspan=2| Home team !colspan=2| Away team ! Attendance |- |3 October 1999 || [[1999 Rugby World Cup|1999]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool A || {{Ru|SCO}} || 29 || {{Ru|RSA}} || 46 || 57,612 |- |8 October 1999 || [[1999 Rugby World Cup|1999]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool A || {{Ru|SCO}} || 43 || {{Ru|URU}} || 12 || 9,463 |- |10 October 1999 || [[1999 Rugby World Cup|1999]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool A || {{Ru|RSA}} || 47 || {{Ru|ESP}} || 3 || 4,769 |- |16 October 1999 || [[1999 Rugby World Cup|1999]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Pool A || {{Ru|SCO}} || 40 || {{Ru|ESP}} || 0 || 17,593 |- |20 October 1999 || [[1999 Rugby World Cup|1999]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Quarter-final play-off 3 || {{Ru|SCO}} || 35 || {{Ru|SAM}} || 20 || 20,000 |- |24 October 1999 || [[1999 Rugby World Cup|1999]] [[Rugby World Cup]] Quarter-final 3 || {{Ru|SCO}} || 18 || {{Ru|NZL}} || 30 || 59,750 |} =====2007===== {|class="wikitable" ! Date ! Competition !colspan=2| Home team !colspan=2| Away team ! Attendance |- |18 September 2007 || [[2007 Rugby World Cup|2007]] [[Rugby World Cup]] [[2007 Rugby World Cup Pool C|Pool C]] || {{Ru|SCO}} || 42 || {{Ru|ROM}} || 0 || 31,222 |- |23 September 2007 || [[2007 Rugby World Cup|2007]] [[Rugby World Cup]] [[2007 Rugby World Cup Pool C|Pool C]] || {{Ru|SCO}} || 0 || {{Ru|NZL}} || 40 || 64,558 |} ===Rugby league=== Although a union stadium, Murrayfield hosted the Rugby League [[Challenge Cup]] Finals of 2000 and 2002. The stadium hosted rugby league's [[Super League]] [[Magic Weekend]] in 2009, taking over from the Millennium Stadium. The record for a rugby league attendance at the stadium is 67,247 for the 2000 Challenge Cup ===Association football=== Murrayfield has also hosted [[Association football]] matches. In December 2003, the SRU board agreed to let local [[Scottish Premier League]] side [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.]] (Hearts) lease the stadium for match days.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/competitions/premiership/hearts-get-go-ahead-for-ground-switch-to-murrayfield-1-496509 |title=Hearts get go-ahead for ground switch to Murrayfield |work=TheScotsman |date=4 December 2003|accessdate=29 October 2017}} Later that month, [[UEFA]] confirmed that Hearts' own ground, [[Tynecastle Stadium|Tynecastle]] did not meet the minimum criteria for European matches from the 2004–05 season.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/heart_of_midlothian/3341135.stm |title=Tynecastle not fit for Europe |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=22 December 2003 |accessdate=5 January 2013}} Hearts used Murrayfield as their home venue for European matches for three years{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/5341280.stm |title=Hearts 0-2 Sparta Prague |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=14 September 2006 |accessdate=5 January 2013}} until Hearts made adjustments to Tynecastle that made it compliant with UEFA regulations.{{cite web |url=http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20040702/tynecastle-stadium-1981-present_2241548_537219 |quote=2005: Plans were produced for a new Main Stand that could take the capacity of the stadium up to 25,000. In the meantime, the removal of 280 seats from the front of the Gorgie and Roseburn Stands allowed the club to extend the length of the playing pitch to meet UEFA Cup requirements. The capacity of the ground is now 17,400. |title=Tynecastle Stadium: 1981-present |work=www.heartsfc.co.uk |publisher=Heart of Midlothian FC |date= |accessdate=5 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130616012023/http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20040702/tynecastle-stadium-1981-present_2241548_537219 |archivedate=16 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Additionally, both Hearts and Edinburgh neighbours [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] have played preseason friendlies against [[FC Barcelona]] at Murrayfield.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/heart_of_midlothian/6920774.stm |title=Classy Barcelona toy with Hearts |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=28 July 2007 |accessdate=5 January 2013}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/hibernian/2456202/Hibernian-handed-six-of-the-best-by-rampant-Barcelona-at-Murrayfield.html |title=Hibernian handed six of the best by rampant Barcelona at Murrayfield |first=Ewing |last=Grahame |work=Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |date=25 July 2008 |accessdate=5 January 2013}} Almost 58,000 people attended to watch Hearts play Barcelona in July 2007, recording the largest crowd at a football match in Edinburgh for 51 years.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/spfl/champions-league-celtic-to-play-at-murrayfield-1-3074428 |title=Champions League: Celtic to play at Murrayfield |first=Graham |last=Bean |publisher=The Scotsman |date=5 Sep 2013 |accessdate=15 May 2014}} In 2014 Glasgow club [[Celtic F. C.|Celtic]] played two qualifying matches at the stadium due to [[Celtic Park]] being unavailable because of Glasgow's hosting of the [[Commonwealth Games]]. Murrayfield was a candidate to replace Hampden as the national football venue for the early parts of Scotland's [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualification]] campaign due to Hampden's renovation for the aforementioned games. However, it was decided that one of the two stadiums in Glasgow would be used.{{Citation needed|date=February 2014}} Hearts again used the stadium for home games during the [[2017–18 Scottish Premiership]], due to the delays in construction of a new main stand at Tynecastle.{{cite news |url=http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/sport/football/hearts/hearts-to-stage-games-at-murrayfield-due-to-main-stand-delay-1-4521745 |title=Hearts to stage games at Murrayfield due to main stand delay |first=Barry |last=Anderson |publisher=Edinburgh Evening News |date=3 August 2017 |accessdate=4 August 2017}} ===American football=== Murrayfield has played host to [[American football]] and was one of two home venues for the now defunct [[Scottish Claymores]] in the [[NFL Europa]] between 1995 and 2004, the other being [[Hampden Park]] in [[Glasgow]]. Additionally, it hosted [[World Bowl '96]] on 23 June 1996. It has been mentioned as a potential future host site for the [[NFL International Series]], should the [[National Football League]] add future games outside the series' current permanent home, [[Wembley Stadium]] in [[London]]. ===Music=== [[David Bowie]] played to a capacity crowd of 47,000 people in 28 June 1983.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=i8JAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_KUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3422%2C5998294 |title=Acclaim in the rain |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=29 June 1983 |page=1 |accessdate=24 October 2017}} On 30 June 1996, [[Tina Turner]] played at Murrayfield as part of her [[Wildest Dreams Tour]]. In September 1997 [[U2]] played at Murrayfield as part of their [[Popmart Tour]].{{cite news |url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/12294390.U2_criticised_for_holding_Murrayfield_concert/ |title=U2 criticised for holding Murrayfield concert |work=The Herald |date=3 September 1997 |accessdate=29 October 2017}} On 3 June 1999, [[The Rolling Stones]] played to 51,000 on their [[No Security Tour]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/360765.stm |title=The Stones (and the years) roll on |work=BBC News |date=4 June 1999 |accessdate=24 October 2017}} On 8 July 1999 [[Celine Dion]] performed her [[Let's Talk About Love World Tour]] as she sold out the full venue of 67,000, on her first ever show in [[Scotland]]. In July 2005, Murrayfield hosted the final [[Live 8]] concert, [[Edinburgh 50,000 – The Final Push]], with performances including [[James Brown (musician)|James Brown]], [[Texas (band)|Texas]] and [[The Proclaimers]]. [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] played a sold-out show on 17 June 2009, as part of their world tour. Some antisocial behaviour at this event affected the stadium's licensing arrangements when they were reviewed a few months later.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/murrayfield-ordered-to-bid-for-booze-licence-before-every-gig-1-1215584 |title=Murrayfield ordered to bid for booze licence before every gig|work=The Scotsman |date=18 August 2009 |accessdate=24 October 2017}} This was the last time Oasis would play a concert in Scotland and the second time they had played the stadium, the first being on their [[Standing on the Shoulder of Giants Tour]] in 2000.{{Citation needed|date=February 2014}} [[Bon Jovi]] performed at the stadium on 22 June 2011 as part of their tour.{{cite web|url=http://www.bonjovi.com/permanent/show/22K1S1v2 |title=Bon Jovi Live 2011 Tour Page |publisher=Island Records |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727103512/http://www.bonjovi.com/permanent/show/22K1S1v2 |archivedate=27 July 2011 }} [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performed to a sell-out crowd of 52,160 on 21 July 2012 as part of her [[MDNA Tour]]. On 3 June 2014, [[One Direction]] performed to over 64,000 fans at Murrayfield as part of their [[Where We Are Tour (One Direction)|Where We Are Stadium Tour]]. [[Foo Fighters]] performed at Murrayfield Stadium as part of their [[Sonic Highways World Tour]] on 8 September 2015. The band were originally supposed to play Murrayfield on 23 June 2015 but this was cancelled and rescheduled after [[Dave Grohl]] broke his foot at European Festival that same month. ==See also== {{Commons category|Murrayfield}} *[[Rugby union in Scotland]] *[[Sport in Scotland]] *[[Scottish Women's Rugby Union]] ==Notes and references== {{reflist|40em}} ==External links== *[http://www.scottishrugby.org/bt-murrayfield-stadium BT Murrayfield Stadium] on the Scottish Rugby website {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Rugby World Cup Sevens]]

page.title: North Korea at the 1998 Asian Games
North Shore Beach and Yacht Club

revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = North Shore Yacht Club | nrhp_type = | image = 2018 North Shore Beach and Yacht Club 02.jpg | caption = North Shore Beach and Yacht Club in 2018 | location = 99-155 Sea View Dr.
[[Mecca, California]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|31|10|N|115|56|14|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = California#USA | area = | built = 1959 | architect = [[Albert Frey (architect)|Albert Frey]] | architecture = [[Modern architecture|Modern Movement]] | added = September 28, 2015 | mpsub = Architecture of Albert Frey MPS | refnum = 15000640{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/nr/listings/20151009.htm|title=National Register of Historic Places Program: Weekly List|date=October 9, 2015|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=2018-05-26}} }} The '''North Shore Beach and Yacht Club''' or '''North Shore Yacht Club''' is an [[Albert Frey (architect)|Albert Frey]]-designed building in [[North Shore, California]]. (Not built as originally designed by Frey.) [[Image:GreetingsFromNorthShoresm.gif|left|thumb|Scan of historic postcard depicting the North Shore Yacht Club on its bottom half]] It opened in 1959 as part of a $2 million development along the northeastern shore of the [[Salton Sea]] which would become California's largest [[marina]]. Several prominent figures from the entertainment industry docked boats there, among them members of [[The Beach Boys]], [[Guy Lombardo]], [[Jerry Lewis]] and [[The Marx Brothers]]. Ever-increasing salinity from agricultural runoff from both the [[Coachella Valley]] and [[Imperial County, California|Imperial County]] combined with fluctuating water levels culminated in a major flood in 1981, destroying the club's [[jetty]] and making it impossible for boats to dock at the club; it would be completely closed by 1984. However the club remained in use by the community into the early 1990s. Like the majority of the buildings which surround it, the North Shore Beach and Yacht Club was abandoned and vandalized. The shoreside swimming pool remained intact though badly vandalized as well. An often-photographed large advertising sign for [[Texaco|Texaco Marine]] at the site of the jetty has now been removed. In July 2009, Riverside County supervisors approved the reception of a grant of $3.35 million as part of an overall package of $30 million to redevelop and restore the property.http://www.mydesert.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2009907220309 News of redevelopment funds at Mydesert.com The property was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2015. North Shore Beach and Yacht Club is pictured on the [[Album cover]] of [[Minutes to Midnight (Linkin Park album)|Minutes to Midnight]] by [[Linkin Park]]. ==Salton Sea History Museum== [[Image:North Shore Yacht Club 2.jpg|thumb|150px|left|After closing in 1984 the abandoned Yacht Club was in a state of disrepair, as seen when this picture was taken, until its restoration in 2010]] On May 1, 2010, the restored yacht club was reopened to the public as the '''Salton Sea History Museum,''' serving as a community center as well as a museum. The former pool area then served as an activity deck while the former loading area became a children's play area.http://saltonseamuseum.org/ Salton Sea History Museum The museum was temporarily relocated to [[Mecca, California]] at the site of [[Desert Cahuilla Wetlands Temal Pa'lekish]] while awaiting a lease agreement from the county and reinstatement of its space in the yacht club. The reopening date was February 3, 2012. The following year the owner of the property, the Torres Martinez Tribe, opted to revoke the agreement in order to make use of the space remodeled by museum volunteers. As of 10-2014 the museum is still awaiting the long-promised lease agreement from the county to reopen in the yacht club. The property that was the North Shore Beach and Yacht Club is owned by [[Riverside County, California|Riverside County]], which made the decision to relocate the museum, and the property is now reserved for rare community events.[http://mobile.nytimes.com/2014/03/23/travel/exploring-modern-ruins-in-southern-california.html?_r=0&referrer= "Exploring Modern Ruins in Southern California"], "New York Times" (March 14, 2014). {{Portal|Inland Empire}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons cat}} * [http://saltonseamuseum.org Salton Sea History Museum] – official site * [http://www.sci.sdsu.edu/salton/PeriscopeSaltonSeaCh7-9.html The Salton Sea: California's Overlooked Treasure at sci.sdsu.edu] * [http://wikimapia.org/1854419/North-Shore-Yacht-Club-Abandoned Aerial view at Wikimapia.org] * [http://www.richardheeps.co.uk/browse/saltonsea/ Photographs of the yacht club in its abandoned condition and surrounding area at Richardheeps.co.uk] [[Category:Historical society museums in California]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1962]] [[Category:1962 establishments in California]] [[Category:1984 disestablishments]] [[Category:2010 establishments in California]] [[Category:Museums in Riverside County, California]] [[Category:Coachella Valley]] [[Category:Maritime museums in California]] [[Category:History museums in California]] [[Category:Clubhouses in California]] [[Category:Salton Sea]] [[Category:Sports venues on the National Register of Historic Places in California]] [[Category:Albert Frey buildings]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Riverside County, California]]

{{coord|38|35|28|N|121|26|17|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Papa Murphy's Park | nickname = | logo_image = [[File:Papa_Murphy's_Park_logo.jpg|125pxpx]] | image = [[File:Bonney Field 2015-05-20.jpg|250px]] | address = 1600 Exposition Blvd
[[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[California|CA]] 95815-5104 | location = [[California Exposition|Cal Expo]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = March 2014 | opened = June 20, 2014 | owner = Cal Expo | operator = [[Comcast Spectacor|Spectra]] | surface = | architect = | dimensions = | tenants = [[Sacramento Republic FC]] {{small|([[USL Championship|USLC]]) (2014–present)}}
[[Sacramento Express]] {{small|([[PRO Rugby]]) (2016)}} | former names = {{plainlist| * Cal Expo Multi-Use Sports Field Facility {{small|(planning/construction)}} * Bonney Field {{small|(2014–17)}} }} | construction_cost = $3 million
{{small|(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|3000000|2014}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})}} | seating_capacity = 11,569 }} '''Papa Murphy's Park''' (formerly known as '''Bonney Field''') is a sports venue located on the grounds of [[California Exposition|Cal Expo]] in [[Sacramento, California|Sacramento]], [[California]]. The [[soccer-specific stadium]] has a capacity of 11,569 and includes a full-sized (120 x 80 yard) soccer field. Papa Murphy's Park is the current home of [[Sacramento Republic FC]] soccer team and former home of [[PRO Rugby]] team, [[Sacramento Express]]. The field is located on the former site of the [[Cal Expo Amphitheatre]]{{cite web |url=https://soccerstadiumdigest.com/2016/08/bonney-field-could-become-music-venue/ |title=Bonney Field Could Become Music Venue |last1=Spedden |first1=Zach |last2= |first2= |date=August 1, 2016 |website=Soccer Stadium Digest |publisher=August Publications |access-date=July 19, 2018}}, and is bordered on the west and south by the Cal Expo monorail, and on the east by [[Raging Waters Sacramento|Raging Waters]] water park. ==History== Construction of the stadium began in March 2014, following approval by the Cal Expo Board of Directors. Funding for the stadium came from an agreement between Ovations Food Services, Cal Expo, and the Republic FC. Original schedules put the grand opening for the Republic FC's June 7 match against [[Arizona United SC|Arizona United]], but that date was postponed two weeks, with the grand opening falling instead on June 20, when the Republic FC played the reserve team of the [[Colorado Rapids]] in a match that ended in a victory for the Republic. {{citation needed|date=September 2015}} The name of the stadium was originally Cal Expo Multi-Use Sports Field Facility, but on April 21, 2014, Republic FC President Warren Smith announced a multi-year deal with Bonney Plumbing, Heating, Air and Rooter Service for the naming rights of the stadium and the name was changed to Bonney Field.[http://www.bonney.com/press_releases/first-home-match-at-bonney-field-moved-to-june-20 "First home match at Bonney Field moved to June 20"] On March 9, 2017, Republic FC announced that the facility would be renamed Papa Murphy's Park, in a multi-year naming rights agreement with [[Papa Murphy's]].[http://www.sacrepublicfc.com/news_article/show/767655?referrer_id=2875420] ==Structure== Papa Murphy's Park is open-ended, with the south endline lacking a grandstand but hosting the VIP section.[http://bonneyfield.com/tickets-seating/seat-map/ "Bonney Field Seating Map"], Bonney Field. The north endline is home to the Tower Bridge Battalion, the SRFC supporters group.[http://www.kcra.com/news/crews-race-to-finish-bonney-field-expansion/32254022 "Crews Race to Finish Bonney Field Expansion"], KCRA, April 8, 2015. The team benches and premium seating are located along the west sideline. ==Soccer== Papa Murphy's Park is the home stadium for the [[Sacramento Republic FC]] soccer team of the [[United Soccer League|USL]].[http://www.sacrepublicfc.com/matchday/bonney-field/#.U5kJPBw2KXI "Bonney Field"], Sacramento Republic FC. The Republic hosted its first match at Papa Murphy's Park on June 20, 2014. In addition to USL Pro matches, Papa Murphy's Park also hosted Republic friendly matches against visiting foreign teams, such as [[Liga MX|Mexican Premier Division]] team [[Club Atlas]], [[Scottish Premiership]] team [[Rangers F.C.]] and [[Premier League]] team [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.]].[http://www.sacbee.com/2014/06/11/6476481/republic-fc-will-play-liga-mx.html "Republic FC will play Liga MX team at Bonney Field on July 6"], Sacramento Bee, June 11, 2014. ==Rugby== Papa Murphy's Park was the home of the [[Sacramento Express]] that played in the [[PRO Rugby]] competition.[http://www.bizjournals.com/sacramento/news/2015/11/18/its-official-sacramento-will-get-rugby-team.html "It's official: Sacramento will get team in nation's first pro rugby league"], ''Sacramento Business Journal'', November 18, 2015. Papa Murphy's Park has hosted several international rugby matches:[http://www.rugbytoday.com/elite/san-jose-sacramento-pnc-home-matches "San Jose, Sacramento for PNC Home Matches"], Rugby Today, February 19, 2015. {| class="wikitable" |- !Date !Team #1 !width=65px|Result !width=110px|Team #2 !Competition !Attendance |- | June 21, 2014 || {{ru|USA}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 38–35 || {{ru|CAN}} || [[2014 IRB Pacific Nations Cup|Pacific Nations Cup]] ||style="text-align:center;"| 7,804 |- |rowspan="2"| July 24, 2015 || {{ru|FIJ}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 30–30|| {{ru|SAM}} ||rowspan="2"| [[2015 World Rugby Pacific Nations Cup|Pacific Nations Cup]] ||style="text-align:center;"|5,500 |- | {{ru|USA}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 23–18 || {{ru|JPN}} ||style="text-align:center;"|11,000 |- | June 25, 2016 || {{ru|USA}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 25–0|| {{ru|RUS}} || [[2016 mid-year rugby union internationals|friendly]] ||style="text-align:center;"| N/A |- | February 8, 2018 || {{ru|USA}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 29–10 || {{ru|CAN}} || [[2018 Americas Rugby Championship|Americas Rugby Championship]] ||style="text-align:center;"| 2,500 |- |} ==Expansion== After a successful inaugural season for the Republic FC, which consisted of 16 sell-outs in 17 matches and a USL Pro championship at Papa Murphy's Park, Smith indicated plans to expand the stadium by 2,000 to 3,000 seats for the 2015 USL Pro season.[https://www.si.com/soccer/planet-futbol/2014/10/01/sacramento-republic-mls-expansion-usl-pro-warren-smith "Republic FC wins first USL Pro championship, will expand stadium"], Sports Illustrated, October 1, 2014. The expansion project, which forced a reschedule of the 2015 home opener, added approximately 1,300 sideline seats, 2,500 endline seats, and an expanded market area. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.sacrepublicfc.com/papa-murphys-park Stadium page] {{Sacramento Republic FC}} {{PRO Rugby}} {{USL Venues}} [[Category:Sports venues in Sacramento, California]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in California]] [[Category:Soccer venues in California]] [[Category:2014 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2014]] [[Category:Sacramento Republic FC]] [[Category:USL Championship stadiums]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Parque Kukulcán Alamo | nickname = Kukulcán Alamo Park | native_name = Parque Kukulcán | image = Kukulcan Alamo Park Sunset.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = A sunset in Kukulcan Park (2015) | location = C 28 x Circuito Colonias Col. Morelos Oriente. C.P. 97174.
[[Mérida, Yucatán|Mérida]], [[Yucatán (state)|Yucatán]], [[Mexico]]{{Cite web|url=http://leonesdeyucatan.com.mx/contacto.php|title=Contacto|language=Spanish|accessdate=2011-06-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722224454/http://www.leonesdeyucatan.com.mx/contacto.php|archivedate=2011-07-22|df=}} | coordinates = {{Coord|20|56|28.36|N|89|35|45.54|W|region:MX_type:landmark|display=it}} | opened = 1982{{Cite web|url=http://law.marquette.edu/cgi-bin/site.pl?2130&pageID=4382|title=minor.baseball.11.p1|accessdate=5 July 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303223725/http://law.marquette.edu/cgi-bin/site.pl?2130&pageID=4382|archivedate=3 March 2011|df=}} | renovated = 2015 | owner = [[Leones de Yucatán]] | dimensions = '''Left Field''': 330 ft
'''Center Field''': 400 ft
'''Right Field''': 330 ft | tenants = [[Leones de Yucatán]] | seating_capacity = 14,917{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/mexico/yucatan_peninsula.shtml|title=World Stadiums - Stadiums in Mexico :: Yucatán Peninsula|accessdate=2011-06-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926212243/http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/mexico/yucatan_peninsula.shtml|archivedate=2011-09-26|df=}} }} '''Parque Kukulcán Alamo''' (Kukulcán Alamo Park) is a [[stadium]] located in the city of [[Mérida, Yucatán]], [[Mexico]]. It is primarily used for [[baseball]], and is the home field of the [[Leones de Yucatán]] (Yucatán Lions) [[Mexican League (baseball)|Mexican League]] baseball team. It holds 14,917 people and was opened in 1982.{{Cite web|url=http://leonesdeyucatan.com.mx/estadio.php|title=Estadio KukulKan|language=Spanish|accessdate=2011-06-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722224459/http://www.leonesdeyucatan.com.mx/estadio.php|archivedate=2011-07-22|df=}} The stadium is named for [[Kukulkan|Kukulkán]], the [[Maya civilization|Maya]] feathered serpent [[deity]]. ==See also== * [[Estadio Carlos Iturralde]] - a football stadium in Mérida ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Mexican League ballparks}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beisbol Kukulkan}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Mexico|Kukulkan]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1982]] [[Category:Mérida, Yucatán|Estadio de Beisbol Kukulkan]] [[Category:Sports venues in Yucatán]] [[Category:1982 establishments in Mexico]] [[Category:Mexican League ballparks]] {{mexico-sports-venue-stub}} {{baseball-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{ infobox venue | coordinates = {{Coord|55.9331929|-4.3045163|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | image = [[File:Murray Park.JPG|300px]] | location = Auchenhowie, [[Milngavie]] | opened = 4 July 2001 | owner = [[Rangers F.C.]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = £14 million | architect = }} The '''Rangers Training Centre''', currently known as '''The Hummel Training Centre''' for sponsorship reasons,<ref name=hummel/> is the [[training ground]] of [[Rangers F.C.]], located in [[Milngavie]], [[East Dunbartonshire]], Scotland. It was opened in 2001 and originally named '''Murray Park''' after the then Rangers owner [[David Murray (Scottish businessman)|David Murray]]. It is also often referred to as '''Auchenhowie''', the name of the locality within Milngavie where it is situated.
== History ==
===Development and opening=== Prior to the construction of the club's own training facility, the first team trained at several locations across [[Glasgow]] including [[Ibrox Stadium]], [[Bellahouston Park]] and the [[Hamilton Crescent|West of Scotland cricket ground]]. A dedicated training complex was first proposed by the then manager [[Dick Advocaat]] upon his arrival at the club in June 1998. It was officially opened on 4 July 2001 by Advocaat and then-chairman [[David Murray (Scottish businessman)|David Murray]], after whom it was originally named as Murray Park.<ref name="Rangers unveil new training complex">{{ cite news | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/r/rangers/1422680.stm | title = Rangers unveil new training complex | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 4 July 2001 }}</ref> The total cost of the complex was estimated at around £14 million.<ref name="Rangers unveil new training complex"/>
=== Purchase by Green's consortium and use as a security === On 14 June 2012, after the [[Administration and liquidation of The Rangers Football Club Plc]], the training facility was sold along with other Rangers' assets, in a deal worth £5.5m, to [[Ownership of Rangers F.C.|The Rangers Football Club Ltd]] - a consortium led by [[Charles Green (businessman)|Charles Green]].<ref>{{ cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-18447530 | title=Charles Green completes Rangers purchase despite Walter Smith bid | publisher=BBC News | date=14 June 2012}}</ref> In July 2014, there was speculation that the Rangers board was looking to sell the facility in order to raise money, due to a fan boycott of season tickets.<ref>{{ cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/rangers/10996605/Rangers-board-face-accusations-from-Union-of-Fans-that-they-are-planning-to-sell-Murray-Park-training-facility.html | title=Rangers board face accusations from Union of Fans that they are planning to sell Murray Park training facility | author=Roddy Forsyth | date=28 July 2014 | publisher=Telegraph Media Group|work=The Telegraph }}</ref>
=== Renaming === The use of the name Murray Park significantly reduced after the club was sold to [[Craig Whyte]] in 2011.<ref name="Dave King Fan Response #3"/> Moreover, after the liquidation of the club and its assets, many fans held David Murray partly or wholly responsibly,<ref>{{ cite news | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/news/13944277.Spiers_on_Sport__The_truth_hurts__but_not_as_much_as_the_damage_done/ | title=Rangers cheated and the truth is unpalatable, the damage irreversible | publisher=Herald & Times Group|work=HeraldScotland | author=Graham Spiers | date=4 November 2015 }}</ref> and so began calling the facility Auchenhowie (after the geographic area where it is based).<ref name="Dave King Fan Response #3">{{ cite news | title=Dave King Fan Response #3 | url=http://rangers.co.uk/news/headlines/dave-king-fan-response-3/ | publisher=Rangers FC |work=Rangers.co.uk|author=Dave King | date=21 June 2016 }}</ref> In June 2012, the then Rangers [[chief executive officer|Chief executive]] Charles Green stated he would ask Rangers season ticket holders to vote on renaming the club's training ground.<ref name="Rangers' Murray Park training ground may be renamed">{{ cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/18348451 | title=Rangers' Murray Park training ground may be renamed | publisher=BBC Sport | author=Keir Murray | date=6 June 2012 }}</ref> Green proposed that it could be renamed the [[Moses McNeil]] Academy or the [[Davie Cooper]] Academy after former Rangers players.<ref name="Rangers' Murray Park training ground may be renamed"/> In June 2016, then chairman [[Dave King (businessman)|Dave King]] revisited the issue of the renaming of Murray Park and asked Rangers fans to suggest an alternative name.<ref>{{ cite news| title=Dave King wants Rangers fans to rename Murray Park | url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/teams/rangers/dave-king-wants-rangers-fans-to-rename-murray-park-1-4160578 | publisher=Johnston Publishing|work=The Scotsman | author=Gavin McCafferty | date=21 June 2016 }}</ref>
In June 2018, the facility was officially renamed The Hummel Training Centre as part of a sponsorship deal with [[Denmark|Danish]] sportswear company and current club kit manufacturer [[Hummel International|Hummel]].<ref name=hummel>{{ cite news | url=https://rangers.co.uk/news/headlines/the-hummel-training-centre/ | title=The Hummel Training Centre | date=14 June 2018 | publisher=Rangers Football Club | work=Rangers.co.uk|accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref>
==Future developments== In February 2016, the [[Rangers Fans Fighting Fund]] revealed plans to provide £450,000 to build a 264-seater stand at Murray Park.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/football/14289607.Rangers_Fans_Fighting_Fund_proposes___450_000_Murray_Park_stand_development/ | title=Rangers Fans Fighting Fund proposes £450,000 Murray Park stand development | author=Christopher Jack | publisher=Herald & Times Group| work=HeraldScotland | date=19 February 2016}}</ref> Planning permission was granted in December 2017 which included the stand and further dressing room facilities, as well as a classroom area and additional floodlighting. Work began in January 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://rangers.co.uk/news/headlines/training-centre-enhancement-granted/| title=Training centre enhancement granted| publisher=Rangers FC |work=Rangers.co.uk| date=15 January 2018}}</ref>
==Structure and facilities== The site covers a size of thirty-eight [[acres]] (over fifteen hectares). It is divided into three areas: the administration wing, the professional wing for the first team and the youth development wing. The professional and youth wings have their own separate receptions, dining areas, changing rooms, kit stores and lecture rooms.<ref name="Murray Park1">{{ cite news | title=MURRAY PARK | url=http://rangers.co.uk/club/murray-park/ | work=Rangers.co.uk | publisher=Rangers FC | accessdate=21 June 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160704063237/http://rangers.co.uk/club/murray-park | archive-date=4 July 2016 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Both share facilities including the gym, medical suite and the indoor synthetic pitch. Outside there are six full size pitches along with two half sized, and a practice area.<ref name="Murray Park1"/> Two of the full-sized and one half-sized pitch are used only by the first team, these have under-soil heating, the others are used by the youth sides.<ref name="Murray Park1"/>
The gym equipment, costing £150,000, is linked to a computer system which can activate a personalised fitness programme for individual players.<ref name="Murray Park1"/> The gym also houses an iso-kinetic machine, which allows players to work out despite being injured by testing muscle strength and reactions. There is a hydrotherapy pool that has an angled, movable floor and a series of massage jets and currents that allows a range of rehabilitation exercises to take place.<ref name="Murray Park1"/> There is also a media editing suite costing £50,000 where a video analyst will video each training session.<ref name="Murray Park1"/> The footage will be used to conduct tactical lessons in the lecture room afterwards.
== Other uses== Rangers training centre is often used by visiting club and national teams playing in Scotland. For example, the [[South Korea national football team]], then managed by Advocaat, hired the facilities for their training before the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{ cite news | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_20060528/ai_n16697207| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111020175840/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_20060528/ai_n16697207/| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 20 October 2011| title = Prodigal boss returns | publisher = | date = 28 May 2006 | author=Stewart Fisher|via=FindArticles.com}}</ref> In February 2015, [[Inter Milan]] trained at the centre after Rangers agreed to allow the [[Italy|Italians]] use of the facility prior to a [[UEFA Europa League]] match against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].<ref name="Rangers to hand Inter Milan keys to Murray Park ahead of their Europa League showdown with Celtic">{{ cite news | url = http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/rangers-hand-inter-milan-keys-5169102| title =Rangers to hand Inter Milan keys to Murray Park ahead of their Europa League showdown with Celtic | publisher = Media Scoland|work=Daily Record | date = 17 February 2015 | author=Ashleigh McGinley}}</ref> This was not the first time Rangers offered support to a club that were to play city rivals Celtic, having made a similar offer to [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] in 2013 and [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] (who were managed by [[Graeme Souness]]) in 2002.<ref name="Rangers to hand Inter Milan keys to Murray Park ahead of their Europa League showdown with Celtic"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://rangers.co.uk/club/rangers-training-centre/ Rangers Training Centre] Rangers FC
{{Rangers F.C.}}

{{Infobox| bodystyle = class="infobox" style="width:22em; font-size:90%;" | above = WHA Hall of Fame | abovestyle = background-color: #005AAB | subheader = | image1 = | caption1 = World Hockey Association logo | headerstyle = background-color: #005AAB | header1 = | label2 = '''Established''' | data2 = 2009 | label3 = '''Location''' | data3 = 801 Hat Trick Avenue, [[Eveleth]], [[Minnesota]] | label4 = '''Founder''' | data4 = Timothy Gassen | label5 = '''Inductees''' | data5 = 30 Players
4 coaches
6 Builders
1 On-ice officials
10 Legends of the Game
4 The Howe Family
55 total | header20 = | header30 = | header40 = | header50 = | below = }} The '''World Hockey Association Hall of Fame''' is an independent organization dedicated to honoring the [[World Hockey Association]] (WHA) which operated from 1972 to 1979 as a major professional [[ice hockey]] league.[http://insidehockey.com/wha-hall-of-fame-recalls-greatness WHA Hall of Fame Recalls Greatness | INSIDE HOCKEY][http://www.greatesthockeylegends.com/2010/08/wha-hall-of-fame.html Greatest Hockey Legends.com: WHA Hall of Fame] Officially partnered with the [[United States Hockey Hall of Fame]], the WHA Hall of Fame permanent museum displays are located within the United States Hall of Fame museum in [[Eveleth, Minnesota]],[http://www.whahof.com/whaexhibits.html WHA HOF Exhibits] with touring displays made available to be viewed at select locations and for special events.[http://metronews.ca/sports/713980/sports-hall-of-fame-installs-wha-exhibit/ Sports Hall of Fame installs WHA exhibit | Metro] ==Ballots and voting== In 2009, the voting ballot, which had been reviewed by members of the [[Society for International Hockey Research]] and the president of the [[International Hockey Hall of Fame]], was distributed to former WHA players and personnel, media members, and invited hockey notables.[http://www.whahof.com/hofmembers2.html WHA Hall of Fame Members 2] All WHA veterans were eligible for induction. The inaugural members of the WHA Hall of Fame were announced in 2010, with 41 indivividual members, plus [[The Howe Family]] ([[Gordie Howe|Gordie]], [[Marty Howe|Marty]], [[Mark Howe|Mark]], and [[Colleen Howe]] who were inducted as a family), making up the initial group of inductees. Eight additional individual members were inducted in 2012. The Hall of Fame also includes ten individuals as "Legends of the Game" who are included in recognition of their "significant contributions or career start in the WHA".[http://www.whahof.com/hofmembers.html WHA Hall of Fame Members] ==List of members of the WHA Hall of Fame == {|class="wikitable sortable" !Name !Category !Year elected |- |{{sortname|Serge|Bernier}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Christian|Bordeleau}} |Forward |2012 |- |{{sortname|Robbie|Ftorek}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Anders|Hedberg}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Bobby|Hull}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Andre|Lacroix|André Lacroix (ice hockey)}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Danny|Lawson}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Rich|Leduc}} |Forward |2012 |- |{{sortname|Larry|Lund}} |Forward |2012 |- |{{sortname|Ulf|Nilsson|Ulf Nilsson (ice hockey)}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Kent|Nilsson}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Terry|Ruskowski}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Marc|Tardif}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Mike|Walton}} |Forward |2010 |- |{{sortname|Tom|Webster|Tom Webster (ice hockey)}} |Forward |2012 |- |{{sortname|Ted|Green}} |Defenceman |2010 |- |{{sortname|Al|Hamilton}} |Defenceman |2010 |- |{{sortname|Ron|Plumb}} |Defenceman |2010 |- |{{sortname|Rick|Ley}} |Defenceman |2010 |- |{{sortname|Paul|Shmyr}} |Defenceman |2010 |- |{{sortname|Lars-Erik|Sjoberg}} |Defenceman |2010 |- |{{sortname|Pat|Stapleton|Pat Stapleton (ice hockey)}} |Defenceman |2010 |- |{{sortname|J. {{distinguish|text=[[Zugzwang]], meaning a situation where a chess player is forced to move and any move will disadvantage the player}} The '''zwischenzug''' ([[German language|German]]: {{IPA-de|ˈtsvɪʃənˌtsuːk|pron}} "intermediate move") is a [[chess]] [[Chess tactic|tactic]] in which a player, instead of playing the expected move (commonly a {{chessgloss|recapture}}), first interposes another move posing an immediate threat that the opponent must answer, and only then plays the expected move {{harvcol|Hooper|Whyld|1992|p=460}} {{harvcol|Golombek|1977|p=354}}. It is a move that has a high degree of "[[Initiative (chess)|initiative]]". Ideally, the zwischenzug changes the situation to the player's advantage, such as by gaining {{chessgloss|material}} or avoiding what would otherwise be a strong continuation for the opponent. Such a move is also called an ''intermezzo'' {{harvcol|Cox|2007|p=216}}, ''intermediate move'' {{harvcol|Kasparov|2008|p=208}}, or ''in-between move'' {{harvcol|Burgess|1997|p=494}} {{harvcol|Horowitz|Reinfeld|1954|pp=180–97}}. When the intermediate move is a [[check (chess)|check]], it is sometimes called an "in-between check" {{harvcol|Horowitz|Reinfeld|1954|pp=183–85}}, "zwischenschach" {{harvcol|van Perlo|2006|p=479}}, or "zwischen-check" {{harvcol|Mednis|1997|p=270}}. As with any fairly common chess tactic, it is impossible to pinpoint when the first zwischenzug was played. Three early examples are Lichtenhein–[[Paul Morphy|Morphy]], [[New York City|New York]] 1857; [[Samuel Rosenthal|Rosenthal]]–[[Cecil De Vere|De Vere]], Paris 1867; and [[Savielly Tartakower|Tartakower]]–[[José Raúl Capablanca]], [[New York City|New York]] 1924. The first known use of the term zwischenzug, however, did not occur until 1933, when the prolific [[United States|American]] chess authors [[Fred Reinfeld]] and [[Irving Chernev]] used it in their book ''Chess Strategy and Tactics''. {{chess notation|pos=toc}} == History == {{Chess diagram small |tright |Lichtenhein–Morphy,
New York 1857 |rd| | |qd|kd| | |rd |pd| |pd|bd| |pd|pd|pd | | |pd| | | | | | | |bd|pd|pl| | | | | | | |bl| | | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl| | |rl |Position after 10.Bxe4 }} No one knows when the first zwischenzug was played, but it was evident long before the term itself existed.[[Master (chess)|National Master]] Dennis Monokroussos observes that "just because authors didn't use the ''word'' 'zwischenzug' doesn't mean they didn't use the ''concept'' – perhaps they simply used 'in-between move' instead". [http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/posts/1145816614.shtml Fred Reinfeld and the Zwischenzug] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807155148/http://chessmind.powerblogs.com/posts/1145816614.shtml |date=August 7, 2007 }} One early example was Lichtenhein–Morphy, New York 1857.[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1224554 Lichtenhein–Morphy, New York 1857] In the diagram at right, White has just captured Black's [[knight (chess)|knight]] on e4 and surely expected the recapture 10...dxe4 11.0-0, when White's king is safe and he has the better [[pawn structure]]. Morphy, the strongest player of the day, instead played the zwischenzug 10...Qh4![https://web.archive.org/web/20091028044450/http://www.geocities.com/lifemasteraj/lich-morp1.html Lichtenhein–Morphy, First American Chess Congress, 1857] Now White cannot save the bishop, since a move like 11.Bf3?? is met by 11...Qxf2#. Moreover, 11.0-0 would be met by 11...Qxe4 12.Nc3 Qg6 (not 12... Qh4? 13. Nxd5!), when "Black has the [[bishop pair|two bishops]] and a compact position without serious weakness" {{harvcol|Reinfeld|Soltis|1974|p=53}}. Instead, White correctly played 11.Qe2 (forcing Black to weaken his [[Pawn (chess)|pawns]]), but then erred with 11...dxe4 12.Be3? (after 12.0-0!, Black has only a slight advantage)''Encyclopedia of Chess Openings'', Volume C, Third Edition, Šahovski Informator, 1997, p. 301 n.72. Bg4! 13.Qc4? Bxe3!! and Morphy went on to win a {{chessgloss|brilliancy}}. {{harvcol|Réti|1976|pp=32–36}} {{harvcol|Reinfeld|Soltis|1974|pp=51–54}} {{clear}} {{Chess diagram small |tleft | | | |rd| | |rd|kd| |pd|pd| |bd| |pd|pd|pd | |qd| | |pd| | | | | | |pd|pl| | | | |bl| | | |pl|nd| | | | |bl| |nl| | |pl| | | |ql| |pl|pl |rl|nl| | |kl|rl| | |Position after 16.Bxb4 }} Rosenthal–De Vere, Paris 1867,[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1255356 Rosenthal–De Vere, Paris 1867] is another 19th-century example of a zwischenzug {{harvcol|Hooper|Whyld|1992|pp=107–8}}. De Vere (Black) had earlier [[sacrifice (chess)|sacrificed]] a [[chess piece|piece]] for two pawns. White has just played 16.Bxb4. Instead of recapturing with 16...Qxb4+, De Vere first played the zwischenzug (specifically, a zwischenschach) 16...Rc1+! After 17.Kd2 Rxf1 18.Qxf1 Qxb4+ 19.Ke2 Qxf4 20.Qg1 Nxe5, De Vere's zwischenzug had netted him two more pawns, leaving him with the {{chessgloss|material|material advantage}} of [[Chess piece relative value|four pawns for a knight]]. White resigned after twelve more moves. {{clear}} {{Chess diagram small |tright |Tartakower–Capablanca,
New York 1924 |rd|bl|bd|qd|kd| | |rd |pd|pd| | | |pd|pd|pd | | | | | |nd| | | | | | | | | | | |bd|pd|pl| | | | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl| | |bl| |pl|pl |rl|nl| |ql| |kl|nl|rl |Position after 9.Bxb8 }} Another prominent example that brought the concept of zwischenzug, albeit not the term itself, to public attention was Tartakower–Capablanca, New York 1924.[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1076242 Tartakower–Capablanca, New York 1924] This was a game won by the reigning [[World Chess Championship|World Champion]] at one of the strongest [[tournament]]s of the early 20th century.[[Chessmetrics]] ranks New York 1924 as the ninth strongest tournament between 1900 and 1930. [http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/Summary.asp?Params=190030SS3SS3S000000000000111000000000000010100 Strongest Tournaments 1900–1930] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120530234656/http://chessmetrics.com/cm/CM2/Summary.asp?Params=190030SS3SS3S000000000000111000000000000010100 |date=May 30, 2012 }} In the position at right, Tartakower (White) has just played 9. Bxb8, thinking he has caught Capablanca in a trap: if 9...Rxb8, 10.Qa4+ and 11.Qxb4 wins a [[bishop (chess)|bishop]] {{harvcol|Tartakower|du Mont|1975|p=295}}. However, Capablanca sprang the zwischenzug 9...Nd5!, protecting his bishop and also threatening 10...Ne3+, [[fork (chess)|forking]] White's [[king (chess)|king]] and [[queen (chess)|queen]]. After Tartakower's 10.Kf2 Rxb8, Capablanca had regained his piece and went on to win in 20 more moves. Note that after 10.Bf4 (instead of 10.Kf2), Black would not play 10...Nxf4??, which would still allow 11.Qa4+, winning a piece. Instead, after 10.Bf4 Black would play a second zwischenzug, 10...Qf6!, attacking the bishop again, and also renewing the threat of 11...Ne3+ {{harvcol|Alekhine|1961|p=208 note h}} {{harvcol|Reinfeld|1974|p=230}}. After a move like 11.Qc1, Black could either take the bishop or consider yet a third zwischenzug with 11...Bd6. {{clear}} {{Chess diagram small |tleft |Euwe–Breyer | | |kd|bl| | | | |pd| |pd| | | | |pd | | | | | | |rd| | | | | |pd|nd| | | | | | | | |nd| | | |nl| | | | | |pl|pl|pl| | | |pl|pl | | | | | |rl| |kl |Position after 27.Bxd8 }} Alekhine, Reinfeld, and Tartakower and du Mont do not call 9...Nd5! a "zwischenzug" in their books (originally published in 1925, 1942, and 1952, respectively). Instead, they refer to it as, respectively, "a bit of finesse", a "sly interpolation", and an "intermediary manoeuvre" {{harvcol|Alekhine|1961|p=208 note e}} {{harvcol|Reinfeld|1974|p=230}} {{harvcol|Tartakower|du Mont|1975|p=296}}. The earliest known use of the term zwischenzug did not occur until after all of these games. According to chess historian [[Edward Winter (chess historian)|Edward Winter]], the first known use was in 1933.[http://www.chesshistory.com/winter/extra/earliest.html Edward Winter, Earliest Occurrences of Chess Terms]. Retrieved on 2009-04-27. Fred Reinfeld and Irving Chernev, annotating the game [[Max Euwe]]–[[Gyula Breyer]], Vienna 1921, called Breyer's 27th move, 27...Nge3!, "an important ''Zwischenzug''" {{harvcol|Reinfeld|Chernev|1933|p=48}}. The game can be played over [http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1033550 here]. {{clear}} == Additional examples == {{Chess diagram |tright | | | | | | | |kd| | |qd| | | |pd|pd| | | | | | | |pd| |pd| | | | | | |rd | | | |ql| | | |rl | | | | | | |rd|pl | | | | | | |pl| | | | | | |bl|kl| |Black now moves 1...Rxh4?; White responds with a zwischenzug. }} The diagram shows another example. Black, on move, plays : '''1...Rxh4?''' expecting White to play 2. Qxh4, when Black retains a material advantage. However, White has a zwischenzug: : '''2.Qd8+!''' which is followed by : '''2...Kh7''' : '''3.Qxh4+ Kg8''' : '''4.Qxg3''' and White has won a [[rook (chess)|rook]], leaving him with a winning position.[https://web.archive.org/web/20091026193715/http://www.geocities.com/Athens/Delphi/6551/zwis.htm Tutorial]{{clear}} ===Mieses–Reshevsky=== {{Chess diagram |tleft |Mieses–Reshevsky, 1935 | | | | |rd| |kd| |pd|pd| | | |pd|bd|pd | | | | | | |pd| | |pl| |qd| | | | |pl| |pd| | | | | | | |pl| | |nl|pl| | | |ql| | |pl| |pl | | |rl| | | |kl| |Position before 29.Nd4 }} A zwischenzug occurred in [[Jacques Mieses|Mieses]]–[[Sammy Reshevsky|Reshevsky]], Margate 1935.[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1224094 Mieses–Reshevsky, Margate 1935] From the position in the diagram, play continued: :'''29. Nd4 Bxd4''' :'''30. cxd4''' White must have expected 30... Qxd4 31. Qxc4 Re1+ and then 32. Kg2 gets him out of trouble, but Black has a zwischenzug: :'''30... Re4!''' Making a {{chessgloss|double attack}} on the d-[[pawn (chess)|pawn]] and preventing the capture of his own pawn. Now if 31. Qxc4, 31... Re1+ forces 32. Rxe1 and White loses his queen {{harvcol|Chernev|1965|p=211}}. {{clear}} ===L. Steiner–Helling=== {{Chess diagram |tright |L. Steiner–Helling, 1928 |rd| |bd| | |rd|kd| | | |pd| | |pd|pd|pd |pd| | |bd| | | | | |pd| | | | | | | | | |pl| | | |qd | |bl|pl| | |ql| |pl |pl|pl| | | |nd|pl| |rl|nl|bl| |rl| |kl| |Position after 15...Nxf2 }} L. Steiner–Helling, Berlin 1928,[http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1280329 L. Steiner–Helling, Berlin 1928] provides another example of the zwischenschach (in-between check). Black has just captured White's [[Pawn (chess)|pawn]] on f2 with his knight. White responded with '''16.Qxf2''', expecting the {{chessgloss|skewer}} 16...Bg3??, which he would refute with 17.Qxf7+! Rxf7 18.Re8#. Instead, Black first played the zwischenschach '''16...Bh2+!''' Now 17.Kxh2 Qxf2 loses White's queen. The game continued '''17.Kf1 Bg3!''' Not seeing the point, White blithely continued with his plan: '''18. Qxf7+?? Rxf7+''' Now White realized that he is in check (that was the point of 16...Bh2+!), so his intended 19.Re8# is illegal. The forced 19.Bxf7+ Kxf7 would leave Black with queen for rook, an easily winning material advantage, so '''White resigned''' {{harvcol|Horowitz|Reinfeld|1954|pp=178–80}} {{harvcol|Golombek|1977|p=354}}. {{clear}} ===Kerchev–Karastoichev=== {{Chess diagram |tleft |Kerchev–Karastoichev, 1965 |rd| | | | |rd|kd| |pd|pd| | | |pd|bd|pd | | | |pd| | |qd| | | | |pd| | | | | | |pl| |nd|pl| | | | | | |pl|rl| |pl |pl|pl|ql| |bl| | |kl |rl| | | |bl| | | |Black to move }} In the game between Zlatozar Kerchev and Emil Stefanov Karastoichev, Black moved : '''1... Ng5''' discovering an attack on White's queen. White moved: : '''2. Qxg6''' (If White moves the queen to another square, Black's knight captures White's rook on f3, winning [[The exchange (chess)|the exchange]].) Instead of immediately recapturing the queen, Black played : '''2... Nxf3+''' and White must get out of check. After : '''3. Bxf3 hxg6''' Black had won the exchange {{harvcol|Burgess|2000|p=47}}. {{clear}} ===Carlsen–Anand=== {{Chess diagram |tright |Carlsen–Anand, WCC 2013, game 5 |rd| | | | | | |rd |pd| | |bd|kd| |pd|pd | |pl|pd| |pd| | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |pd| | | |pl| | | |pl|bl| | | |pl| | | | |pl|pl | | |kl|rl| | | |rl |Position after 20...fxe4 }} In [[World Chess Championship 2013#Game 5, Carlsen–Anand, 1–0|game 5]] of the [[World Chess Championship 2013|2013 World Chess Championship]] match, [[Magnus Carlsen|Carlsen]] had captured a bishop with 20.cxb6, and [[Viswanathan Anand|Anand]] maintained material balance by capturing a knight with 20...fxe4, also attacking White's bishop (see diagram). Instead of immediately taking the pawn with 21.Bxe4, which would have given Anand the opportunity to fix his queenside pawn weaknesses with 21...axb6, Carlsen played the zwischenzug 21.b7. After the necessary 21...Rab8 and 22.Bxe4 Rxb7 Anand's a- and c-pawns remained [[Isolated pawn|isolated]]. Black's weaker pawn structure was an important factor to Carlsen's initiative in this first decisive game of the match. {{clear}} ==See also== * [[List of chess terms]] * [[Combination (chess)]] * [[Go strategy and tactics#Sente and gote|Sente]] and [[Tenuki]] (from [[Go (board game)|Go]]) ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{Citation |last=Alekhine|first=Alexander|authorlink=Alexander Alekhine |year=1961 |title=The Book of the New York International Chess Tournament 1924 |publisher=Dover |isbn= 978-0-486-20752-0}} *{{citation | last=Burgess |first=Graham |authorlink = Graham Burgess | title=The Mammoth Book of Chess | publisher=Carroll & Graf | year=1997 | edition = 1st | isbn= 0-7867-0431-4}} *{{citation | last=Burgess |first=Graham | title=The Mammoth Book of Chess | publisher=Carroll & Graf | year=2000 | edition = 2nd | isbn= 978-0-7867-0725-6}} *{{Citation |last=Chernev|first=Irving|authorlink=Irving Chernev |year=1965 |title=The Most Instructive Games of Chess Ever Played: 62 Masterpieces of Chess Strategy |publisher=Dover |isbn= 0-486-27302-4}} *{{Citation |last=Cox|first=John |year=2007 |title=Starting Out: Sicilian Sveshnikov |publisher=Gloucester Publishers |isbn= 978-1-85744-431-5}} * {{Citation |last=Golombek|first=Harry|authorlink=Harry Golombek |title=Golombek's Encyclopedia of Chess |year=1977 |publisher=Crown Publishing |isbn= 0-517-53146-1}} * {{Citation |last=Hooper|first=David|authorlink=David Vincent Hooper |last2=Whyld|first2=Kenneth|authorlink2=Kenneth Whyld |title=[[The Oxford Companion to Chess]] |year=1992 |edition=second |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |isbn= 0-19-866164-9}} * {{Citation |last=Horowitz|first=I.A.|authorlink=I.A.
